GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Inexpensive and works great in my small-form-factor PC
Customer Review:
I need a graphic card upgrade for a very old compact desktop PC, Acer Aspire A3910 from 2010. This  MSI GeForce GT 710  is an entry-level graphic card that fits my requirements perfectly. Here are several reasons why I picked this card instead of something more powerful:
- It is relatively inexpensive.
- It is low profile and occupies only one PCI slot. This is important since my PC has a SFF (small form factor) case with limited space.
- It consumes very little power (20W max), so even the 220W power supply in my PC can handle it.
- It uses only heatsink for passive cooling. This eliminates the noise and reliability problems associated with cooling fans.

[Installation Confusion]
- Initially right after the graphic card was installed, I can only get a display of 1200x800 from the HDMI port. Nothing from VGA port.
- After I installed the MSI VGA Drivers from disc, my monitor can now display 1920x1080 from VGA port, but nothing from HDMI port.

The problem could be from my computer's motherboard, since I observed the same behavior with the  EVGA GeForce 210  I previously purchased (and returned). Just keep this behavior in mind, in case you cannot see any display right after installing the card.

[Graphic Performance]
I ran the 3DMARK 'Cloud Gate' benchmark on my PC, both before and after the graphic card upgrade:
- With integrated graphic, the overall score is a pathetic 209.
- After installing the GT 710, the score jumps up to 3735!
(see my uploaded screenshots for details)

On the other hand, the GT 710 cannot hold a candle against my better graphic card, the  EVGA GeForce GTX 750 Ti . When both cards were tested in a newer desktop PC ( Asus M32CD ), the 750 gives about 4x higher score . Note that the 750 does not fit in my old SFF PC since it is much larger. See my photo uploaded for size comparison between 710 and 750.

[Power Consumption]
I used the  EUM-A1 Power Usage Meter  to measure the input power of my computer:
- Before the graphic card upgrade, my computer consumes ~50-55W when idle, ~70-75W when running 3DMARK.
- After the upgrade to GT 710, my PC consumes the same 50-55W when idle. This means this graphic card has the same standby power as the integrated graphic chip set.
- When running 3DMARK or  XCOM: Enemy Unknown , my PC now consumes up to 85-90W. That means the graphic card consumes 15-20W when it is running at full speed.

After I played XCOM for several hours, the heatsink becomes too hot to touch, but not hot enough to cause a shutdown. In contrast, the EVGA GeForce 210 suffers thermal shudown after just ~10-20 minutes of playing XCOM. This is because the 210 consumes more power (30W vs. 20W) but comes with a smaller heatsink.

[Conclusion]
The GT 710 works very well in my particular situation. Of cause this is an inexpensive entry-level card, so I cannot expect the same level of performance as my GeForce GTX 750 Ti. But for a very small investment, I'm suddenly able to play many games which were previously unplayable on my old SFF PC. For that I'm happy.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: A Faster, More Powerful 10 Year-Old Gateway Desktop
Customer Review: I generally don't write reviews, but since I did a fair amount of research before purchasing this for an older computer, I'm hoping that this information will assist potential buyers. I was looking for a way to boost the performance of an old Gateway SX2801-01e, thin profile desktop. It was maxed out on RAM (8 GB), but for whatever reason, just couldn't seem to generate graphics smoothly and without struggling. Not gaming, mind you, but for place-shifting and streaming video, and having multiple applications open. This card fit in the sole expansion slot for a PCI x16 card. My main concern was that the dated BIOS would be too ancient, or that the card would simply freeze up the computer. Neither happened. It booted into low-resolution at first while the drivers updated automatically. But after the updates and a couple of reboots, I was back in business. This old desktop has new life, as it runs like a new computer. (I had already migrated to a Samsung SSD and added a USB 3.0 card.) The built-in 2GB or RAM is supremely helpful. I'm also running with a 220W power supply, and not the recommended 300W without issues. It consumes a mere 19W. I'm going to upgrade my older monitor with a higher-resolution one now that the graphics card can support it.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
Fit like a dream, worked easily, installation was a cinch on every level.

Instructions are not included for installing the low profile bracket. What you do:
Use a pair of needle nose pliers and unscrew the long bracket by twisting the little bolts that you woudl normally screw the video cable into. Just pinch the sides of each bolt and give little short twists (lefty loosey) until it comes loose, keep track of your bolts, and then once all four are out, you can easily separate the VGA socket (at the top in the main picture). The included short profile brackets are pretty obvious for placement, just watch the orientation. You'll end up using two of your external slots, but only the one PCI slot on the motherboard. The little bolts screw back in to the new brackets, and it's just fast and simple. I don't even think I ended up using a screwdriver at all, but the case we have was pretty much made for fast, painless installation without tools. The pliers are a must, though.

While this does say it requires a 300w power supply, it's running absolutely fine on a 240w power supply. Didn't even have to plug it in to a separate power cable (which is good, because there wasn't one.) We're using it for older Steam games (Spore, for example) for my kid, on a Windows 7 machine we bought for $250, and this upgrade brings the machine pretty painlessly up to a decent standard for a lot of games. Just don't try to max your graphics out, because you don't want to overheat a fanless card.

Anyway, I'm pleased. Oh, and everything comes packaged with little red caps over the connectors, which makes handling it a lot less nerve wracking while you're figuring the brackets out. A card I can hold easily while dicking around with the bracket? Thank you! They recommend using rubber gloves to avoid nicks, and I didn't, but this still may be the first time I've installed a video card when I didn't end up bleeding.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)

I need a replacement video card as I need the video card for my PC. I'll buy a different brand and send this one back to Amazon if that is their support.
Update 11/26/18: Are these cards not any good? Should I return this one for credit and purchase a better card. After purchasing this card, the HDMI slot lost the sound. I contacted the vendor and they wanted it returned for repair. It was only a week or so old. Instead of sending it in, I paid another $9 or so for a DVI to HDMI adapter cable and used the DVI slot on the card. I received sound and pictures for about 3 months and ow the sound has gone out on the DVI slot on the card. I did not want to return it as then my PC is out of video and sound until they take their sweet time to repair a $30 card rather than ship me a new one. GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Works just fine and plays Fortnite on lowest settings
Customer Review:
I bought this for my son's PC as he wanted to play Fortnite on his PC at times.

There was originally only 4GB of RAM on the machine and integrated graphics. It would not even play Fortnite. After adding the graphics card it would play but did lag or would even crash some times. I then upgraded the RAM with an additional 8GB (4GB x 2 sticks) for a total of 12GB. Now he says it plays pretty smooth with no lagging or crashing. He wasn't looking to build a gaming rig and just needed a better graphics card over what was integrated.

His specs:
Dell Vostro 460
i5 processor
12GB RAM
320GB 7200 RPM HD

I also bought the 4 year warranty on it for $1.54, so he can nuke it and I don't care. :)

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Great for 1080p video, dies at 4K (it's a 710)
Customer Review:
MSI is one of my go-to graphics card companies. Their quality is great, their cards perform well and their Afterburner software is second to none.

Let's be up front about one thing here: a GT 710 is a GT 710. If you're looking for a gaming card, even just to play Windows Store games, look to at least a 730 or, better, a 750 Ti for entry level gaming.

With that behind us, let's talk about reasonable expectations for a 710. The purpose of a 710 is to give an old computer with no digital video output an HDMI jack. It's to beef up a PC with vintage 2006 integrated graphics and allow it to work with modern displays. It's my expectation that if a graphics card supports a given resolution, be that 1080p, 1440p or even 4k, that it will be capable of smooth video playback at that resolution. I chose this 710 for my HTPC because it supports 4k resolution, and I just needed my ancient PC to push 4k video. That's it.

And here's where this card failed me. 4k video playback was subpar. It was choppy, the HDMI audio cut in and out, and it wasn't just one source. YouTube, local content, it all looked bad. 1080p was much better, but the 4K display did it no favors.

The 710's saving grace was that it was able to push convincing 1080p video to a 1080p monitor, and maybe that's really all it's useful for. If that's your use case, and for plenty of people I'm sure it is, this is a decent, cheap card for you.

Mine was returned. I didn't even bother goofing around with overclocking or temperature testing because I just didn't see a need to. The 710 clearly wasn't quite enough for my needs.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Great low cost product with Windows 10 Fall Creator Update (build 1709) Support
Customer Review: This was a forced purchase under extreme budget limitations. It replaced old ATI HD 4600 series graphics cards which developed issues with dual monitor with the original Windows 10 creators Update and new blue screen issues with the Fall Creators Update. While ATI stopped supporting their product in 2015, Nvidia still releases a solid set of drivers that support the latest version of Windows 10. This MSI version of the GT 710 is very flexible. It supports both low profile (2 slots with brackets included), and standard profile (only 1 slot needed), and is cable of driving 2 HD monitors with ease. Compared to the HD 4650 it was replaced with, the 2d images and text see clearer and the colors more vibrant, even on 15 year old monitors running analog. Even though this is not a gaming card, it holds its own for the light to casual gamer and does not need a lot of power from the PSU to do so.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Weak Performance but Does the Job Well
Customer Review:
Inexpensive for a brand new video card. Solid DXVA capabilities for an HTPC. Worked great to replace a dying 7600GS in my dad's computer. Very low power.

Passive cooling might not be enough for this card if you task it alot and have a case with very low airflow. My dad's small form factor PC saw it running in the 80s celsius just running some light games. I attached a slim low-noise 40mm fan to it with a ziptie and that was easily enough to cool it down. Now it never gets above 60*C when playing games for hours. So be aware the cooler is just too small to be a good passive cooler for games and DXVA in a super tight case. In a case with better airflow this is probably less of an issue.

It's paired with a C2D E7500 Wolfdale 2.93Ghz and 8GB DDR-2 800 RAM so not an amazing PC but enough to push this card along well enough. It runs Youtube, Netflix and Media Player Classic with 1080p mkvs smoothly. It has HDMI output which makes it good for our occasional HTPC needs. Again the card does DXVA okay, but not amazingly. Combined with the CPU it's more than enough to handle high bitrate 1080p which is the goal. So for that it's pretty useful despite the low performance. Better at DXVA than the 7600GS by a longshot.

Modern features but very weak performance. Runs older games somewhat worse than the ancient 7600GS it replaced, and newer games just a little better. This card isn't intended for games, but it would be nice to see it perform more like its specs. It's not as disastrous as the GT210 was, with simply broken performance, but it's pretty weak.

That said, it runs Source games okay with the settings scaled back, and runs Battlefield 1942, Call of Duty/UO and lots of other popular older games. My dad uses it to play Rome Total War and Medieval 2 nearly cranked which makes him happy. Runs most lighter-weight newer games with low settings as well. So it's not totally helpless, but it's not meant to compete as a gaming card. AMD's APUs are much faster than this, and the integrated in newer Intel CPUs is also much faster. For my dad's older PC though, this MSI GT710 was a perfectly reasonable replacement part.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Just works. Great for business use!
Customer Review:
I needed a video card quickly to get my office PC back up and running. For some reason, my old video card stopped outputting 3840x2160 @ 30Hz (30 frames/sec), and went back down to 1080p. Because my monitor at the office is 3840x2160, that meant I only had 1/4 as much space for windows, and my productivity was hurting.
My old card, a Radeon HD 5450, required that I use drivers from 2012 to let me drive that video timing out on HDMI. But one fateful day, even the old drivers refused to send it, with no explanation as to why. I also had to rig up a little device to keep the HPD (Hot Plug Detect) signal from going away when I turned my monitor off, or the Radeon would switch to the DVI output. Every. Single. Time. It was really frustrating.
So I went and got this, because I was just looking for a card with the following:
- It outputs 3840x2160 @ 30Hz on HDMI
- It's silent
- Low power
I did about 5 minutes of research, found this, verified on nVidia's website that it would do it (it's spelled out that it will), and whipped out my credit card and hit "Order Now." I ordered it on Thursday, and Amazon had it to me on Friday (even though it was normal Prime 2-day shipping). Bonus.
So I crack open my mid-tower, find the old card covered in dust (but it was also a fanless card, and the dust blew right off, no probs), and slap this in. The driver install took ages (gotta have all of those patches and tweaks for games I won't be playing...) and eventually I was back up and running. With this card, 3840x2160 showed up, and was marked as preferred. And when I turn off my monitor and turn it back on again later, it didn't switch to DVI because it decided to. Excellent.
To summarize:
- Works with 2016 drivers in 4K, unlike some other budget cards
- Doesn't decide spontaneously to switch to DVI from HDMI
- I'm happy with it

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Fine card. Not the best but it'll get the job done.
Customer Review:
This is an older card of course so I can't recommend it for newer gaming. But It can keep up with maybe 80% of my steam library, which has lots of games pre-2016. Just don't expect to do some seriously high-end gaming and you're probably fine. Always check the game's specs and if a card is still in support when looking for what you need.

It was A BUTT to get the screws out to install it into the case because they were in so tight, but everything else about the install went smoothly. We have an HD monitor, and everything looks great. Supports the sound to said monitor as well. NVIDIA drivers are fantastic because they let you know when there's an update unobtrusively and they're very simple to install. Just a few clicks and 1-2 screen flashes and you're done. Supports dual monitors.

This went into a half-tower with an offensively small power supply (300w) so I had to unplug the blu-ray drive but it is working fantastically. For the price, I really have no complaints. It's been working great, and since the card is still in support, you'll continue to get drivers so your games don't crash suddenly. Or cook itself to death, like the card it replaced.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Dual monitors on a Dell Optiplex
Customer Review:
This GPU was purchased for a very specific purpose. It is not and should not be marketed as a "gaming" card. I have a ~2015 Dell Optiplex that has a half-height form factor that I use at my work. The motherboard on the Dell only supports a single VGA output and I really prefer a dual-monitor setup for productivity. I had an old XFX-branded Radeon HD5450 in the case that was doing dual-monitor duty just fine for all this time running Windows 7. When Windows 7 support ended my computer had to be reformatted and a fresh Windows 10 install was done with UEFI and Secure Boot enabled. What we discovered was the BIOS/UEFI changes that were necessary were incompatible with the old Radeon card.

I picked up this GT 710 for a very specific use case. It had to be small-form factor (low-profile brackets), had to be low-power and passively cooled, able to support multiple monitors outputs, and had to support UEFI. This MSi card fit all the criteria. It comes with the standard bracket installed but took a matter of minutes to put the 2 included low-profile brackets on with the correct tools. I installed it in the computer very easily but I was surprised that the card only took up about half of a PCI-e slot. The physical length of the card only occupies the first half of the slot and it doesn't even engage the PCI-e locking mechanism. Once the card is bolted down it doesn't move.

It booted fine and worked for me without any additional drivers. The Nvidia control panel was even added by Windows without any user intervention. I'm running the card with the stock power supply and running two 1080p monitors, one on HDMI and one with DVI-D. So far so good.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
I'm kinda up in the air about this card since it seemed to take forever to install the drivers for it.
Also, it didn't really improve the performance of the desktop. But I wanted a card with a fan/heat sink assembly so it would run cooler. My old card didn't have one and it ran at about 118 degrees F. This one runs about 95 F. I didn't buy this card for gaming just wanted a decent card to run in my old Dell Optiplex desktop. I don't need the low profile adapters. Mine isn't a small form factor. But it is nice to have those if in the future if needed for anther PC. The plastic covers for the ports and connectors is a nice touch. Aaaahh, I'm pretty happy with the purchase, no complaints here.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
My Father's computer was giving that whining, rattling noise that would come and go. He tolerated it for months. During a visit he was showing me a funny video and the noise started, then went away.... the computer froze. Well, I don't live there so he told me it does that occasionally. He just restarts and.... um. No! I diagnosed a bad fan on the video card. This card arrived quickly, is easy to install and works great for web surfing and emails. My Dad is thrilled with the whisper quiet function too. At only 2gb of video RAM, I would be careful of what games are played with this card. It may run some newer games but I would guess resolutions and detail may need to be lowered to keep frame rates playable.
Overall though, it's a great value for a quality replacement video card for an average computer and user.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
My Acer Aspire TC-885-ACCFLi5O desktop had integrated graphics that were less than optimal for even basic video watching. Glitchy video playback was concerning, so I purchased this card to put into the PCI-express slot.

I purchased this card knowing it was low-profile, which was good. It fit right into the case and snapped in without issue. No need to connect anything beyond that and the whole process took 5 minutes.

The card ships with a driver CD. I installed the drivers and the additional software on the CD but ended up removing the additional software as it related to overclocking and I didn't need it.

I like this card as it costs less than fifty bucks and boosts the overall video performance of PCs with integrated graphics. This 2GB card is better than most of the 1GB cards at around the same price point and provides users with the option to have a dual monitor setup. (I'm using the HDMI port and so far, it works great.)

If you need a cheap card for a system that has integrated graphics, this is one to consider.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: The perfect & inexpensive card for a MacPro (mid-2012, 5.1) upgrade for Mojave, supports 4K!
Customer Review:
(Review is for the GT 710 2GD3 LP)

-----------------------------------------------------

UPDATE 12/17/2019:
I just picked up a new HDTV, the Samsung 43" model UN43NU6900BXZA which offers 4K and UHD. Amazon carries it as does Bestbuy and others locally. It may be a baseline model, but, wow, the pic quality is extremely crisp and clean. The MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB is working perfectly with my new 4K Samsung, using my Mac Pro running Mojave.

This card supports 4K and there was no adjustments in settings needed for setup, the card and my 4K Samsung communicated perfectly and my Mac Pro make the resolution settngs seamlessly in the background upon connecting.
The quality of my Mac Pro now (running Mojave for the present) is stellar. Details, fine text, screen fit, contrast, color...etc...it all looks superb.

If you are considering a 4K display upgrade, YES, this card will work perfectly with it!
---------------------------
I needed an inexpensive card to upgrade my Mac Pro 5.1 mid-2012 and this card works perfectly for that. No power cable needed and a very small profile that won't get in the way of other cards and slots. It is self powered by the PCIe bus so no power cable was needed.

Of course there is no boot screen during boot nor a way to select which drive to boot from if you have more than one OS drive. You can easily though, change the "start-up" drive once the OS is booted and loaded in System Preferences, so not a big deal for me.

I am using the HDMI output to a Samsung 1080 HDTV and there was no need to tweak screen fit or anything. The card booted right up to a perfect screen display.

I've tried a few other Apple recommended cards in the past and honestly, none did any better than this. I returned one at over $150 simply because I decided to wait for a lower priced card to do the same thing and this MSI card does! Additionally, this card seems to wake my Mac out of sleep very quickly. The older cards I tried seemed very sluggish to do that, this card seems much more responsive to wake my Mac. A Win-Win in here!

HMDI won't pass the audio, but, no cards out there will do that unless specifically made for a Mac Pro and flashed correctly. I have optical and digital output on my M. Pro so not a biggie.

The card seems responsive and fast and at some point I will do a "Geekbench" test. The 1080 on my Samsung HDTV looks crisp and clear output from this card. I would say 1080 looks slightly better on this card than my old OEM one that came installed on my Mac. Small icon seems a bit crisper and clearer. Close to the old card, but, there is definitely a bit of improvement there.

The card is fan cooled and since I won't be gaming with this desktop, it should run very cool routinely.

5 Stars all around and a great way to upgrade an older Mac Pro on the cheap.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: This has proved to be an excellent upgrade. It replaces the onboard GeForce 9100. GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: Normally, I'm not a big fan of MSI, but took a chance after reading reviews. I have a separate graphics computer as my monster computer. Blah, blah, blah. The card is really small, and that's good. More heat sync and fan than anything. Fired right up and delivers a nice clean picture. So I'm happy. I got what I wanted and looking for at a fair price. So far, I would recommend.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)

Thank you for reading my review:

Again Please give this review a thumbs up. It is real. I do answer questions if in comments. I've been on Amazon as a customer for over twenty years, and now a top 500 reviewer. I don't get compensated for my reviews. (Not that I wouldn't like to be.) I pay for Amazon Prime so I get any of the perks that come with my Prime membership.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: For Playing Star Wars Battle Front
Customer Review:
I bought the new Star Wars Battlefront II game and found out that my video card did not meet the minimum specifications. Bought this card to get me over the playable threshold. It did, though in order to play I had to turn down many of the game's video intensive features. But for our part, it still looks great and play is great, so I'm not complaining. Perhaps I'd sing a different song if I could see the game played on a high end video card, but since I haven't and we aren't all the big of gamers, we are happy with the outcome.

It's quiet, easy to install, and worked immediately.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Windows 10 Support, Low Power, Silent Video Card Solution (LPV1 PCIe x8)
Customer Review:
I bought this card because Windows 10 no longer had support for the Radeon 4250 onboard graphics on one of my PCs. First of all, the LPV1 model is physically a PCIe x8 card, but it will in fact work in a x16 PCIe slot. It's very compact and lightweight so even without the use of the locking tab, it shouldn't have any problems staying securely in place.

When I first booted up, the video card was using Microsoft's Basic Display Driver. So I opened up my browser to download the drivers from nvidia. As I was doing that, my monitor flickered on and off, then I saw that Windows automatically installed the driver software and the card switched to my monitor's native resolution. So if this happens to you, just give your Win 10 PC a few minutes recognize the video card and install the correct drivers.

For basic Windows 10 functionality, web browsing, video streaming, and even light casual games under low settings, this card can handle it pretty smoothly. It's passively cooled with no active fan so it stays silent and it has a TDP of only 19W.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: The ideal GPU for CPU mining rigs that need a dedicated GPU or for servers that need a GPU
Customer Review: If my review headline got you in here, I'll tell you what you need to know in a sec. For everyone else: This is not a good graphics card for gaming. You're probably looking at this because it's cheap. You get what you pay for. Don't buy this GPU and expect to play games with great graphics quality. That was my Public Service Message. Back to the review. If you're building a CPU mining rig with a Ryzen CPU, you'll need a dedicated GPU. This baby fits the bill perfectly. It's inexpensive, has a passive heatsink which means no fan to wear out and eventually get noisy. The heat sink is quite beefy (card is heavier than it looks) actually keeps the thing nice and cool. It also comes with a low-profile bracket, in case you need to shoehorn it into a 2U server case or maybe a very small PC case. Icing on the cake, it's got 2GB of RAM, will do 4K resolution (at least for displaying graphs) and has all 3 of the major video outputs (VGA, DVI, HDMI). Great picture quality, runs cool, uses almost no power and no noise. I own half a dozen of these and you cannot go wrong.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: This card solved the problem I was having
Customer Review: I have a computer with a 5 year old Gigabyte motherboard with an internal Intel graphics card with 32 MB of RAM. The graphics worked fine until I installed 2 new Acer 24 inch LED monitors in a dual monitor configuration (extended). My wife uses this machine for doing data entry and other tasks at work. After installing the new monitors, they "flashed" or "blinked" fairly often. I assumed that the internal graphics system might be getting a bit overloaded so I decided to get this new MSI card. After installing it, the monitors worked great but I noticed that the machine was running slow when I did a right mouse click to get to the graphics configuration. I went ahead and disabled the internal graphics card in the BIOS setup. It was set to "auto." Now the right mouse click works great. I installed the latest NVidia software in "express" mode and unfortunately, it installed some gaming software. Since we don't do any gaming, I uninstalled everything that wasn't necessary for the display (i.e. drivers only). If I had the install to do over again, I would have installed in advanced mode and unchecked everything but the driver only. All in all, I am very pleased with this product and it is doing exactly what we need. My wife even says the displays look more crisp with this card.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Lots of Bang for the Buck for Dell 790 SFF Desktop
Customer Review: I purchased a used 2012 Dell 790 SFF Desktop from Ebay with standard onboard graphics and Display Port (DP) Plug. Passmark Performance Test indicated decent processing capabilities but weak scores for 2D and 3D graphics, about 150 each. For this business desktop the number of compatible graphics cards available is limited due to small form factor, power from the OEM 240 watt power supply, plus I wanted HDMI, not DP. The MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit was an easy install using the included SFF bracket requiring about 20 watts power to operate. The MSI software was a 575 Mb download that updated everything. Passmark Performance Test improved with 2D to 220 and 3D graphics to 620. Overall score went from 756 to 1077, a 42% improvement with HDMI monitor. I am pleased with this card and got a lot of bang for the buck.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Made upgrading a small, underpowered system a breeze.
Customer Review:
Very pleased with this purchase. Tweaking an older HP Win 7 system to run Win 10, I found the poorest performing element was the on-board video capability, or rather, lack of it. The microtower chassis had only one slot on the board and two chassis openings for low profile cards. Because the very compact chassis meant that airflow was poor, I wanted active cooling, even though that would take a few watts of additional power from my seriously undersized 240W PSU.

Although some specs say this needs a 300W PSU, I finally found that this unit generally draws under 20W and since i had only 1 chassis fan, no lights, an efficient, cool running but not SSD HDD, and no additional add-in cards, it seemed a match. With 2 GB of RAM vs. other 1GB versions, this is the best low power performer I found. Any games played are older, and I have left everything at factory settings. Win 10 drivers were easy to install and rock solid. I have not had a single flicker or resolution hiccup in the well over a month period since purchase. Running the latest win 10 builds without any issues. Far from a barn burner, but fine for general computing and way better than the on-board chipset it replaced. The HDD is now the bottleneck, which I bought for size, not speed. Recommended where low profile, low power, and moderate performance demands are your criteria.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
Got this to replace a geforce 285 I bought when I built my PC in 2007. The 285 finally went out and I was stuck between buying a new pc or fixing my 2007 pc.
I saw this thing for $60 and gave it a shot.
Times sure have changed.
My 285 was the size of a small child, took up 2 slots, and required 2 6 pin powe connectors.

This card is barely bigger than my old network card, Runs only onthepower from the pci slot, and is faster.

PC didn't run very well until I updated the driver. It came with a cd , But I went to nvidia to get the latest driver.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: This card can't handle basic media
Customer Review:
I have never been able to make this card work properly. I am not a newbie when it comes to upgrading computers. I knew that I wasn't buying a top of the line card, and I've had Nvidia cards before. I bought this mostly to take advantage of its SUPPOSED 4k capabilities for my new MSI 4k monitor, and to do some pretty light video editing. This card has been very frustrating. I've tried soooo much to fix this thing.

I've even tried it in two different computers.

Specs on computer 1: Intell quad core 3.2GB, 24GB ram.
Specs on Computer 2 (brand new HP): AMD Ryzen quad core 3.1GB, 16GB ram.

The results were the same.

Sometimes I need two video sources open at the same time, playing simultaneously. These video sources are usually local, but occasionally they are streaming. On both computers using this card, whenever I have a video open in VLC and another in WMP, there is terrible stutter and pixel loss. Moving my mouse when ONE video source is playing causes stuttering. Audio and video won't sync properly. If I'm watching a streaming video, I can't also scroll Twitter or Facebook because an autoplay video will completely wreck the streaming video. Plex is as solid a program as any out there, and anytime I try to use Plex to watch local video on this card I get stuttering and audio/video sync issues.

I have a hard-wired 100GB connection, so the stuttering isn't my internet connection.

I had a very old Nvidia card (2GB) that handled all of this really well, including heavy video editing and video compositing. I'm not doing that work much anymore, but the idea that I should try anything like that with this card makes me jiggle with laughter - when I'm not crying for dropping $70 on this thing.

Reached out the Nvidia support. They got right back to me. Gave me complicated instructions to put the right driver on my system. It worked, for a while. When things started to go south again I asked for a replacement, but apparently I have to work with MSI to get a replacement. That will be my next step.

Just beware that this card might not handle basic functions.

ADD: I hooked my monitors up to the onboard graphics of the new HP and everything works fine. This card is now officially junk to me.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Had a bit of trouble installing, but it works perfectly!
Customer Review:
I bought this for an Inspiron 3647 running Windows 10 and it took me ELEVEN hours to figure out how to install it...because I'm a noob. Solution is in last paragraph if you don't want to read about my trials and tribulations.

My pc has only VGA and HDMI for monitor output, and the HDMI quit working. I wanted to have a dual monitor setup and I had an empty PCIe slot, so I figured I'd get a graphics card. My main monitor was VGA and I was hoping to get the 2nd (an old monitor I brought from work so I could work from home during the COVID-19 pandemic) into HDMI. Got the card inserted into the slot and powered everything back up. BLACK SCREEN!!! Not even the integrated graphics VGA worked! I had no clue what to do! I powered down, took the graphics card back out and was able to see via the VGA again.

The product did not come with a cd for the driver, so I went to the NVIDIA website to download it. Got the .exe going, but it wouldn't let me run the install wizard because it couldn't detect the card. (Nooo duhhh...because I had to take the card out to even SEE how to get to the website to download the driver!!!) Only the integrated graphics showed up under display in Device Manager.

I thought that maybe my HDMI cable was bad so I tested them out with the laptop. They worked great. Turns out the old monitor from work was no good. Back to the drawing board. I scoured tons of forums for solutions and pored over them for hours.

One solution was to boot up in safe mode and enable the PCIe slot in BIOS. So, I go to BIOS and there is absolutely NOTHING about graphics, video interface, northbound or southbound (or whatever it is) settings...NOTHING. Spent about an hour trying to read up on BIOS and where else it could possibly be. Couldn't find a thing. So I decided to look up if I should update my BIOS. After all, I was running version A04. I got conflicting answers about whether or not I should - this did not really help me at all.

I tried to find out how I could even update the BIOS...I didn't know where to go. My search led me to Dell's website, where I input the service code of my pc and it showed me about 11 different updates it needed to do - one of which was a BIOS marked URGENT! Matter of fact, it was wanting to update to BIOS version A11!!! No WONDER I was having trouble! Intel's website told me, if I understood it correctly, that I could not use an external graphics card in addition to the integrated graphics card...that only one would be active. That bummed me out because in order to make the graphics card fit, I had to take off the VGA port and install it with the smallest bracket, which only left me with HDMI and DVI. I was hoping to use the integrated VGA and the HDMI on the new graphics card.

Solution: I updated my BIOS to the latest version, enabled Intel Multi-Display in BIOS, and was then able to continue the NVIDIA control panel installation, which enabled my new graphics card. I was also able to use the integrated VGA AND the HDMI on the new graphics card with no trouble! Hopefully, this poor sap is able to help another poor sap out. :)

Con: My only con (other than the legwork required for me to install it - but that is most likely due to my pc being old) is that the fan is noisier than I expected.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: I cannot recommend this, horrendously NOISY!!!!
Customer Review:
Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
 I'm a software dev by day and music producer by night. I used to build high-performance, water cooled PC's for benchmarking competitions years ago, so I know a thing or two about buying computer parts. This past week, I ordered parts and built a mid-budget Micro ATX PC exclusively for producing music. In doing so, I wanted an absolutely dead silent computer. I have a Sterling condenser microphone (for vocal recording) that will pick up birds through walls miles away, so the fans gotta be silent. My build has a very quite and low-power consuming i3 9100f as well as two super quiet Noctua case fans. I very carefully picked out (most) of these parts to build a dead-silent PC. Obviously I made a slip up on this graphics card....

I'm not gaming on this thing, but I did want something that can easily handle 1080p on a 21" monitor as well as potentially support a second monitor, so I bought a budget-end graphics card. Upon reading benchmarks and researching, I've seen good things about the performance out of the GT 710 graphics card. It's awesome that includes 2GB of memory, just a lot of bang for your buck in a daily PC. So I ordered this one. I've had MSI products in the past, including graphics cards, such as the higher-end Radeon HD 7950 graphics cards, which was an awesome GPU in the early 2010's.

I fired up my PC after building. I instantly noticed the sound of a noisy fan constantly running (which infuriated me, as I was trying to go for a dead silent build...). It didn't take me long to figure out it was the graphics card. It is VERY noisy. It sounds like it's running a game constantly with just my desktop open! To demonstrate the noise, I have recorded a video clip. I used MSI Afterburner in the clip to manually adjust the fan speed. As you can see, I have it on the lowest setting in the beginning. I can't lower it anymore, so the fan will always be audible, even at the lowest level. I turned it on max, and you can hear what it would sound like running a game.

I'm honestly shocked how horrendously noisy this graphics card is for it's size. It has a very tiny fan, what looks like a 40mm fan (maybe even smaller). The noise wasn't even something I considered in my research on this card, I did not thing such a low powered card with such a tiny fan would be so noisy! Does it run? It runs great. Desktop is fast and responsive, I have no problem watching videos or movies on it (which I tested). But I CANNOT recommend this graphics card. The noise level is absolutely unacceptable. I don't care if you're building this for a gaming machine, media center, or something else where you didn't think noise would be a factor. This thing is noisy, and every time you shut you PC, you will notice just how bad it is. Shame on you, MSI. I know this is a budget level graphics card, but there is no excuse for this kind of noise.

I'm returning this and replacing it with an Asus GeForce GT 710. same card, but it has a special Asus-designed heatsink with NO FAN. As long as you have adequate cooling like my PC, with good airflow and cable management, you don't need dedicated fan on something like this.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
I put this into an admittedly older Dell computer running Windows 10, and it is working worse than the built-in VGA adapter. Video lags audio and there is a crackling that follows the sound, as though people are trying to speak through cellophane. I set up my 6-year-old laptop running Windows 7 next to the computer and streamed the same video on it and the video ran flawlessly. So it's not the source video.

I also noticed that people appear to have issues finding a Win10 compatible driver for this board. Perhaps this is a great board whose time has gone. Unfortunately for me, I waited too long and my return window has closed. But you don't have to make the same mistake that I did.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Easy Install into older Dell Inspiron.
Customer Review: Package arrived two days early. The actual product box was not sealed nor did it have anything else in it except the videocard and the small form brackets. I wondered if it was an open item but the video card seems wrapped from the factory. I downloaded the software from MSI before install. It was a straight forward install and I connected my monitor up to the VGA for now and booted right up with no issues in Windows 10. I ran the GEFORCE software and it download drivers and updated again. 500megs later the card was installed with no issues. I plan to run another monitor in the very near future and this was the cheapest I could find but it seems like a nice budget card. I have not been into gaming for 15 years or more so I'm sure gamers would want more nowadays. It did speed up my computer by freeing up the motherboard CPU and RAM. I'm very happy with it.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Good for an old Dell Precision workstation
Customer Review: This card was installed on a 6-years old Dell Precision T3600 running Ubuntu Linux 18.04 with dual monitors (Philips 276E8V on HDMI and ViewSonic VX2478 on DVI-D). It was installed on a PCIe x16 slot, although it uses a x8 bus. I used a DVi-to-HDMI adapter to connect it to the ViewSonic monitor, which also gave me sound on this monitor. I used the Linux proprietary driver nvidia-driver-435. I could get 4K resolution at 60hz on the Philips monitor (3840x2160@59.94hz on Philips and 2560x1440@59.95hz on ViewSonic) but I ended up using lower resolutions (2560x1440@59.95hz on both). The glmark2 benchmark gave me a pitiful 591 score, which is low for some games (my 5-year old Quadro 600 gave me a 914 score for the same setup) but is OK for a professional workstation. When I run the glmark2 benchmark, the temperature jumped from 56C to 69C, which I guess is OK for a low profile card without a fan.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: I have a top of the line HP Envy - the unit stopped turning on after a year...I called a few places and they told me it was the Power supply (PS). I watched a video on YT and was able to test the PS which was working fine. I removed the Video cards after checking everything else without success and viola! With the Card off the mother board the computer would turn on...of course without the card you cant use the computer. I ordered this card since everything else i saw cost more than the computer itself! (something about everyone using graphic cards to mine for bit coin) - anyhow, the card is working great, and I think much better quality than the junk HP had put into the system. Works well with no issues. I dont play VG on the PC so I can not rate it for VGs.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Great value for a basic game level card
Customer Review:
This won't be a big long review like I normally write...

I bought this card because I have to remote into a PC via RDP and run software on it. All was well until I wanted to run a game that required a relatively modern DirectX and my system didn't support it.

I didn't want to spend a lot and this was not a hugely graphics-intensive game. I just needed modern DirectX support that would work in a remote connection.

I also didn't want a power guzzling, heat pumping, fan noise-generating video card.

Looking around I found this card at under $55 (at the time of purchase) and it supported DirectX 12. It supports PCI Express 2.0 (yup my PC is a bit long in the tooth) and has VGA, DVI Dual Link, and HDMI so I'm not feeling trapped (other than no display port but what the heck are you going to get for <$55).

Install it, load NVIDIA drivers (they self update after that), and I'm all done. Games work remotely now!

So, if you need a low-end card to support more modern things, you can do worse than this card. I have no complaints and no reservations about giving it a thumbs up.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Works great even my 7 year old intel core i3 LGA 1156 MSI motherboard running Windows 8.1
Customer Review:
Update: 10-01-2020 Good news the driver / software left behind after I removed the card and uninstalled was NOT causing the problems with the built in core i3 CPU's onboard video chip - the heat sink mounted to the CPU had gotten loose and after I locked the plastic intel hold downs all problems went away.

Update: 06-27-2018 still working great on my desktop PC running windows 8.1x but... now and then I have had top reboot. I recently got windows monthly roll up quarterly updates. Closed all programs, installed and rebooted. Then I noticed all windows / programs were solid black. I rebooted and the problem was gone. At other random times I have have had a single program do this. Never happened in the prior 8 years I have owned this computer and running the built in graphics on the core i3 chop. Not a deal breaker but something to be aware of.

Low power consumption!! I used my kill-a-watt meter and on one computer the power consumption was identical to the core i3 with built in video and on the computer I am using now it is around 3 to 5 watts extra at idle compared to before I installed the video card. Running temperature is very cool - I ran the MSI torture test and put my hand on the fan-less heat sink and it was barely warm! Normally it is room temperature.

Excellent. I don't play video games but I do some home video editing with Corel VideoStudio but.... I started using a program called Sketchup (SU) which is used to for architectural building design and 3D modeling in general. The problem is the latest and last two free versions of the program SU 2016 and SU2017 require a newer version of OpenGL. My OpenGL my existing home built computer is a Intel first generation core i3 socket LGA1156 computer with an MSI MS-7587 H57M ED65 chip set motherboard that only supports OpenGL 2.0. I discovered that I could not simply download software driver with a newer version of OpenGL because the hardware I had would not support it. So I started searching for a video card. I had no Idea what card would work but amazingly I discovered that my 7+ year old computer supported PCIE or PCI-E 16X 2.0 which meant I could use almost any video card including this one.

Install.... I highly recommend using backup software that makes a full image of your computer as this is the mother of all installs! I used ghost to backup my windows 8.1 install. I rebooted and then started the install. Wow I was blown away with the size of the driver 1.5 Gigabytes!!!!! WOW - largest driver I have ever installed. Normally, a driver might be a few megabytes!

Next, it asked if I wanted to install the updates. I should have said no and rebooted then installed updates. Result - when I rebooted the screen was blank. I hit the power switch and rebooted and everything is fine. About a day later I had my android phone hooked up by usb to transfer pictures and I disconnected because the copy froze and I was forced to reboot. That problem never happened and fortunately has not happened since.

CONS: invasive - huge huge driver install. I normally, run about 7 programs and tons of tabs in my firefox browser. I minimize everything and set my computer to go to sleep after 20 min and hibernate after 2 hours. When I start the computer up after hibernating and open the programs minimized to the task bar then are reduce in size about 1/3 of the screen and aligned in the top left corner so I have to resize the window. Never had the problem until I installed the video card but I can live with it.

Second con - there is zero performance improve in my system even when using VideoStudio X9. The only thing the video card does for me is allow me to run SketchUp 2017. Possibly I might run dual monitors in the future. The point is that the power and features of the card mainly apply to video games and possibly VR? but for the average desktop user you won't notice a difference with this card or any other brand.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
This review is for the "MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB DDR3" card (GT 710 2GD3H LP).

First off, I'm not a gamer. I just needed a second graphics card so I could use 3 monitors simultaneously. Being fanless is important to me because I use my PC for mixing/recording music and don't want additional noise. Finding a fanless card that supports 3 monitors simultaneously is tough to find. (Amazon doesn't help because they combine questions and reviews for similar models and if the answer/review doesn't explicitly spell out the product model you get conflicting results. For that matter, even the manufacturer specs say "Maximum Displays: 2".

I bought this to run side by side with a Saphire Radeon 6450 which will only handle 2 monitors simultaneously. I was very pleasantly surprised when I got it and the box said it supported 3 monitors max. So I replaced the Radeon, installed the drivers and control panel software and 3 monitors worked great.

Things to note:
1) Windows 10 Pro would not configure 3 monitors from the traditional right-click | Display settings. I had to first use the Nvidia Control panel to tell the card to use 3 monitors simultaneously. Once that was done then Windows could see and manage all 3.

2) For some reason Windows popped a message that Nvidia Control Panel needed to be downloaded from the Windows Store. Comments on the Windows Store indicate that makes LOTS of folks VERY unhappy with Nvidia. I did not download it but just searched for it on my machine and it was there. I think Nvidia drivers did install it but Windows didn't know that until it ran once.

3) The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is that when this card is installed my boot time goes from 15 seconds to nearly 2 minutes. With my old card I get a single system beep from POST then it boots. With this card I get 3 addition POST beeps each approximately 30 seconds apart. I've gotten quick response from MSI Support and will revise the rating should a solution come from it.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Great for upgrading an older computer to be compatible with recent games
Customer Review:
My daughter is using an older desktop computer we have that has a 2nd generation i7 processor. With enough memory, this PC is easily powerful enough for day to day tasks but because it is 2nd generation, the built in intel graphics do not support some of the requirements for games these days (e.g. Fortnite can't run on it, and Minecraft will stop supporting it this fall)
This $35 upgrade made it very possible for her to continue playing these games with her friends at a decent quality (you won't impress anyone with it's awesomeness and get 120fps on high graphics settings -- not by a long shot! but graphic cards that can do that easily cost $300-$800!)

Will this card satisfy an advanced gamer? NO!
Will it make it possible to continue playing decently on an older computer that would be under the minimum requirements? Sure!

Another 2 huge plusses:
- It does not consume a lot of power so our existing (~300W) power supply was more than enough
- It uses only passive cooling! no fan needed = no additional noise at all!

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Wait one more paycheck, and get the step above.
Customer Review:
I received my graphics card in a timely manor. I installed it promptly into my computer. Installation was easy and upon boot it was instantly recognized by Ubuntu 16.04 and then I installed the proprietary Nvidia drivers and began testing it out. Unsurprisingly within the first 15 minutes of testing the card overheated and caused the computer to shut down. I had to install a fan to keep it cool which is not such a big problem for me because I had the parts laying around, but if I was a typical user I would have had to spend another $15 on an additional cooling fan and have to wait another week for delivery. Overall it does what I wanted to do. I only play Cities: Skylines and my kids play the Sims. Would I buy it again? Probably not. Would I recommend it to anyone? Unlikely. If I find myself needing to buy a new card in the future, I'll definitely be buying the step above in the 90 to 100 dollar range.
UPDATE!!! Thinking about it, this graphics card doesn't do as advertised. It is supposed to be passively cooled card. It is not. I'm knocking it down to 2 stars.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Decent energy efficient video card but not for serious gaming
Customer Review:
I gave this GT 710 video card a 5 start rating since it is exactly as described. A decent, basic, energy efficient Nvidia video card that is a smart upgrade from an onboard GPU or an old basic video card that's no longer supported. And the 2 GBs of dedicated memory is a bonus. The GT 710 is not a gaming card and it's not supposed to be. Then again, most folks who own personal computers aren't gamers. I replaced an old GT 220 which was no longer supported.

Installation was easy (in my full sized tower) and Linux Mint (19.1) picked up the new card immediately and updated the driver accordingly. Windows 7 Pro, however, booted up at the low resolution (as to be expected being Windows) and I had to download the latest driver for the 710 from the Nvidia drivers page online. Once downloaded and installed, one reboot was all that was required and resolution was back to normal.

It's very quiet and is reported as drawing only a max of 20 watts. Like I said, the card is not meant for serious gamers but for the majority of folks it does exactly what it's supposed to do.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Looks like a good value for money grahics card.
Customer Review:
I have an Acer TC-885 desk top which came with a 2 gb HDD and I added a spare 1 gb drive I had laying around. I didn't like the on board graphics as you can't change the resolution as its greyed out so I bought a Gigabyte graphics card with a passive heat sink that took up 2 spaces. Now 2 years on I wanted to fit a 1tb SSD as the boot time was slow but the MB had no more sata sockets. No problem, I bought a PCIe dual sata card for the 1 tb HDD but the gigabyte card covered the slot with its heat sink. Hence this long story to buying this MSI graphics card thats only 1 slot wide. I note other users had problems getting the driver and my card had no driver disk but luckily last night I searched the internet to find the driver for Win 10. Its on the Nvidia website and the file name is 446.14-desktop-win10-64bit-international-dch-whql. I extracted it, installed it and within 5 minutes after a restart all was well.

Hope this helps others especially the source for the driver. As for performance, I'm not interested in high end gaming so it isn't a big deal.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
Bought three for our HP and two Dell's.

HP is Core i3 / 8GB / Win 7 Pro x64, I tried all three cards with same results. HP locks up in BIOS screen.

Dell with Intel Quad Core / 8GB / Win 7 Pro x64 or Win 10 Pro x64, these cards work, but there's a crackling sound in audio and streamed video lags with voice out of sync.

I had to put my old video cards on all three PC's and working just fine. Not sure if there's an issue with these MSI video cards or compatibility issues with my PC's. My HP is for couple of years old, and Dell is quite old although they are quad cores.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: I bought this as an Amazon Warehouse deal for an old Dell Inspiron 660 that I wanted to output a 1440p resolution which wasn't supported by the on-board graphics card. The card I received looked brand new, although the one I bought didn't come with a manual, none was needed as installation was a breeze with the card fitting easily into the available PCI slot. Upon boot up Windows 10 booted into a basic graphics driver with low resolution and so I went into device manager to have Windows 10 check for driver updates and it downloaded and installed the proper drivers. I was then able to switch the resolution to 2560x1440 which looks great and so I'm happy with this purchase.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
When mounted in a tower the fins are aimed straight down and there is insufficient cooling by convection. Consequently, the GPU continually overheated and shut the PC down.

A temporary clip-on fan provided temporary cooling that was sufficient, and the permanent solution was a 50mm chassis fan screwed to the fins. Fortunately, the card in the next slot was very short, left the fins exposed, and there was room for the fan.

It was installed in a Win 7 machine upgraded to Win 10. The on-board graphics were not supported in Win 10, so the card was needed. The machine had been deemed too slow for Win 10, but with this card it is actually more responsive under Win 10 than it was under Win 7 with on-board graphics. Not to mention that it is driving a Dell U2518D monitor in 2560x1440 mode (via HDMI) and is super sharp. The machine is not used for gaming, so I can't comment on its speed, but I would guess it is not blazing fast.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: nice upgrade, getting another couple years from this ancient box
Customer Review:
I chose this to prolong my 10yo socket 755 core2quad. This card replaces a Geforce 7300 GT (also fanless) from 2007. I don't do much gaming, but the update was intended primarly to make SC:RE playable. And it works great.
My motherboard only has PCI Express 1, and x16 slot. No problems. Going from 128-bit memory interface to 64-bit didn't seem to be an issue. The new card is lower power, cooler, and supports much more recent OpenGL and DirectX versions. I run Linux, and the Nvidia binary drivers work great. For a cheap upgrade, I couldn't be happier.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
I bought this mainly for two purposes. One is to cover a current monitor which has a top resolution of 1920x1200. But, the embedded Intel video graphics in my PC sometimes resets it to 1920x1080 which I then have to jump through hoops to change. This cards fixes that problem with little cost.

The second purpose allows me to go to a higher resolution with a new 4K monitor and give the older monitor to my wife. She'll need the same upgrade.

I did this on a Dell 3250 PC running an Intel i5 processor and a limited power supply. I worry that I might be overloading the supply but no problems after a few weeks.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Huge FLAW in design of this card
Customer Review: This card should be physically identical to their 2 GB RAM version. It is not in the least. Instead, MSI got cheap and shortened the card size. This shorter version does NOT engage the safety lock on the motherboard and you cannot remove the VGA mini adapter because the heat sink is glued and screwed in place. In addition, I saw that the card does not seat 'perfectly' where it should screw down, which is a huge issue if you have a case where a metal plate presses down to secure 'all in 1' add-in cards, such as a custom InWin thin case or other brands, like Dell and HP. This places a huge threat if you are shipping systems or sell these to customers. This is pure IGNORANCE on MSI design engineers, whose IQs may be high, but have demonstrated an alarming and repeating lack of 'builder' common sense. I also found the same kind of flaws in their 9th gen motherboard connector layouts that made the boards useless for my purposes. I can't fit second video cards in low profile cases because they moved the USB 3 Port to the side of the board where it prevents cards from being fully inserted, making the board useless for two video card solutions. What was MSI thinking?

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Exactly what I needed at a reasonable price !!!
Customer Review:
This MSI GT 710 is exactly what I needed to use my 49" 4K TV as a computer monitor in my DAW music studio setup, as well as general PC usage (web surfing, email, etc.). The HDMI output (3840 x 2160 resolution @ 30 Hz) matches my system and my needs perfectly. A more expensive card with higher performance would have just been overkill, since I am not into gaming or watching movies on this PC.

I was concerned that the card might run hot with passive fanless cooling, but I was pleasantly surprised...the heatsink barely gets warm, and the silent operation in my home studio is a big plus (and I don't have to worry about a fan getting noisy and eventually dying).

As others have mentioned, there was no disk with driver software, but I easily downloaded the driver software from the Nvidia website, and actually didn't want any of the MSI overclocking or utilities anyway.

Low profile, low power, low price and silent ! I am very happy with this card !

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: This is the second GT 710 1GD3H LP that I ...
Customer Review:
This is the second GT 710 1GD3H LP that I have bought in the past 2 months and this one was installed on an EMachines running Win XP Media Edition 64 bit. The first driver download from NVidia for the XP 64 bit OS would not accept the hardware so it refused to install. So I downloaded a 32 bit Win XP driver from NVidia and it installed after flashing a warning screen first then proceeded with the install without any problems. The card runs as smoothly as the other one that I bought previously for a Dell desktop upgraded to Win 10 Pro.
The main snag that some people seem to be having with this card is the install procedure. With the computer off, unplug the video cable from the desktop, install the card, plug the video cable into the card then turn on the computer. After booting, run the NVidia driver for the operating system you are using and the driver will install. You must have a video cable plugged into the card before booting the computer. You cannot preinstall the driver before installing the card.
The card is not expensive and uses only a small amount of power that my 300 watt power supply provides.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
My son was so frustrated trying to play games on his PC because the lag and pauses were horrible. He was, after all, not using a graphics card because I had taken it out when it malfunctioned and connected the monitor directly to the integrated VGA port. I just hadn't figured it would really make any difference... boy was I wrong! So after maybe 2 years of just being connected to the motherboard, I finally purchased this cheap little graphics card, and what a difference it made! Now, my son loves playing his online games and they play fast and smooth with no lag! I also upgraded his drive to a new Samsung 970 EVO SSD and the computer boots up in under a minute! He loves his computer now more than ever. :-)

EDIT: Oops... correction. I purchased for him a Samsung 860 QVO SSD Drive. And that has really made an amazing difference in his computer's performance!

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: No drama install. Clean video playback at lower resolution. But buy one with a fan!
Customer Review:
I put this in a Dell OptiPlex 9010 running Mint Linux. Changed the bracket out to (included short brackets with card) low profile popped it in the Pcix16 and then watched it boot up with no drama.
Will run alright on the generic driver in Mint but Driver manager installed one for it. Nice image, crisp lines and good color balance.
This is not a Gaming card, at least not cutting edge games. I bought it for a PC that I will turn into a home file server and I am happy with it.
Up Date 10/16/2028
Well I only removed one star since I was not surprised that it has trouble with 4K (3840X2160) video I expected it wouldn't do well. It does render static images well what I removed the star over is how hot it runs since it has no fan.
I will save anyone thinking about 4K video who needs a LP card some time. As of this posting date you want a GeForce GTX 1650 D6 OC Low Profile 4G Graphics Card using the GDDR6 RAM. I spent a lot of time comparing LP video cards and that's the one with the best performance I found. Still won't be a great gaming card but it will power via the PCIe slot and will be a lot better than the one above. Of course it's 3X the cost also.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: It appears NVIDIA cards don't play well with windows 10. Mine crashes, or freezes at least once a day and when playing some games, every 20-30 minutes. I've tried everything suggested to fix the issues, and frankly NVIDIA and Microsoft has allowed this to go on for over a year with no real fix in sight from either of them.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Cool product until hardware errors ruin PC stability.
Customer Review:
It is working well in a 240 watt PC. Changing the regular back plate to two low profile back plates was easy. The 2 GB model uses the full width of the PCI Express slot. BIOS and Windows 10 64 bit started using it from the connected DVI port right away. Windows found an Nvidia driver and automatically installed it 8 minutes after booting. Full device and installation took about an hour, with most of it spent waiting for software from MSI and Nvidia's websites to install and update. It's cool to see YouTube videos looking like 60 fps, full color demos at electronics stores. It is a great upgrade from integrated graphics, which struggled with 30 fps 720p streaming video.

The box says the 300 watt power supply requirement is based on a PC with an Intel Core i7 3.2 GHz processor. That's a 130 watt CPU, so my PC with a 65 watt dual core CPU will be fine. The card only needs 19 watts, presumably if it is running 3 monitors at once with detailed game content.

I'm not a gamer, so I doubt the card will ever hit its maximum performance level. I just want smooth video playback, multiple monitor support for my refurbished PC, and the ability to connect to HDMI displays. The card uses a full size HDMI port. A large cable from a DVD player was inserted to confirm it wasn't mini or micro HDMI.

The card was well packaged. It had protective red plastic covers on the connectors. Installing and running 64 bit Blender 2.78c happened nicely without OpenGL support error messages it used to display with integrated Intel G41 graphics. The 3D editing view was very fast and smooth. To my surprise and delight, CUDA and GPU rendering in the Cycles renderer were available. I enabled it and set the tiles to 256x128 with experimental features turned on (256x256 slowed down the Windows interface). It worked much quicker than CPU rendering. Wow. It was my impression that GTX400 and above cards were needed for that. Amazing!

- - -

Update after one month of use: Changed review from 5 to 2 stars. Windows 10 64 bit stops working several times a week with Kepler Live Kernel Event 141 errors. They usually happen while web browsing with two dimensional text and graphics. This hardware isn't PC compatible. No other graphics card or integrated graphics system has ever behaved like the GT 710. There was also terrible mouse lag and mouse cursor disappearance when the card was connected to a 1080p HDTV. It's really annoying to have the display turn black when I'm right in the middle of regular office tasks. I am losing data and having to redo work because of this garbage hardware.

- - -

4 month update. Lowered rating to one star. It should be -100 stars. The card is still having live kernel event code 141 hardware errors once or twice per day. The driver has been repeatedly updated. Clean installs were done. Windows 10 is fully updated. Power management is set to "prefer maximum performance." Quick boot is disabled in BIOS. The computer's power plan is set to high performance. Nothing has helped. If anything, the problems are worse than they were four months ago. I hate this product. It can't reliably handle the taxing situation of displaying a web page while the mouse is moving.

-----------

Final update on day 479 (16 months). It gave a livekernelevent code 117 while attempting to play a YouTube video to a 1360x768 HDTV over HDMI. Everything was fine until it froze, got blocky, and went black. Now the card is removed and in the garbage. I am back to using integrated G41 graphics and an SVGA cable. I had upgraded to the latest Nvidia driver and it apparently had no positive effect. Repasting the GPU had no positive effect. Replacing the power supply did not help. I need order and stability in computer hardware, not chaos, failure, errors, and problems with no solutions. I regret purchasing an MSI and an Nvidia product. Both companies clearly have no clue about making decent hardware, doing quality control, or telling the truth to patient customers who simply want working machines.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
Most of the negative reviews revolve around games or 4K video overheating the card, poor performance, etc. I'm not sure why someone would think this would be a high performing card at the price point. Do some basic research and you will find out it's fine for desktop 4K operations except for some games and videos.

I plugged it into an Acer Aspire AM3470G-UW10P (circa 2012) with 8G RAM running Ubuntu 18.04. Since I already had the proprietary NVIDIA drivers loaded it was detected without further configuration. This card was about 1/2 the price of the ZOTAC GeForce GT 730 I have in another PC. I really cannot detect a difference doing normal desktop activities like browsing, developing, etc.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)

Update: I can’t seem to get any output from VGA
