GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Affordable Video Card That Can Upgrade Older VGA or DVI Only Cards to 2 Gigabyte HDMI, VGA, or DVI.
Customer Review: My 8 year old HP Desktop was crashing with the Blue Screen Of Death. Tried to figure it out and I kept getting messages that indicated an error message. I doubled my RAM to 32 Gigs, replaced all of my hard drives with SSD's, and still got crashes and diagnostics with error messages. Upon further research, Video / Graphics cards also have memory. This was my last hope. I would be happy to get rid of my VGA / DVI dongle I needed to connect my monitor to this tower and I read that two Gigs was much better than one for a graphics card. For gamers, three gigs is even better, but I am not a gamer. I installed this card and got rid of my clunky old cables and ran a slender HDMI cable that I bought on Amazon and SHAZAM! No more crashes. Great graphics. I am stoked.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Obviously its not a gaming card and is DEFINITELY a budget card but it is capable and can do even more if overclocked with something like MSI tuner
Customer Review: Bought this for my sons computer to upgrade his onboard graphics. He plays fortnight for HOURS on end with graphics set on low/medium and view distance to high and gets 30-43fps with no slowing down due to heat. Obviously its not a gaming card and is DEFINITELY a budget card but it is capable and can do even more if overclocked with something like MSI tuner. There are not alot of performance small form factor cards out there but for around $50 if you are looking for something to get the job done than here it is. Obviously its not a 760 or a 970 (my other cards in my other builds I run) but I would buy this again.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: Actually a little surprised. I put this in a old slimline Dell Optiplex that i decided to upgrade and use primarily for a media pc in the gameroom. I first put a intel q9650 (quad @ 3ghz) , upped the ram ddr2 to 6gb, then threw this gpu in. Ran great! Decided to load a game and see how it does. Dishonored on high settings is at a stable 30fps. Very surpised, seeing as how i didnt think this gpu would be able to even play any games at a decent framerate.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: The fan on my old GeForce GT 620 was starting to fail, making rumbling sounds. I figured that if the fan quit the card would overheat and quit, probably at some critical moment. So I got the MSI version of the GT 710, which installed easily in the slot previously occupied by the 620. I restarted the computer, which temporarily reverted to its built-in minimal graphics display. I then went to the NVIDIA web site, found the driver package for this replacement card, downloaded it, and ran it. It quickly installed the new driver, and the screen reverted to the settings I had created under the 620. You can go to the MSI site for the driver, but it will simply refer you to the NVIDIA site. There is no CD provided with a driver, probably because NVIDIA frequently updates its drivers, so downloading assures you get the most recent version.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Just what I needed for dedicated graphics for Photoshop.
Customer Review:
I was having a real problem using some of the new photo post processing software with my integrated graphics system. Finally after consulting with the software techs, as to why it is snail slow, They informed me that even though I have a new Dell, the integrated graphics is my problem. I ordered this dedicated card, and everything is up to speed now, and I didn't have to upgrade the power supply.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Nice upgrade for an older computer
Customer Review: I have been using Nvidia products for years and his seems to be a very decent inexpensive graphics card. I'm not a gamer so no need for for a high $$ card. I purchased this as an upgrade to the integrated graphics card on an older Dell machine. Using newer and larger monitors, some software programs wouldn't display all that well and had some weird artifacts with the graphics rendering. This card solved that problem and now everything appears nice and clean just as it should. Definitely a nice card that won't break the bank for a basic upgrade to an older machine. I also purchased this because it' supports HDMI which I had much rather use than VGA. It was an easy install on Windows 7 Pro 64. Not bad at all for a basic, inexpensive upgrade for an older system.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Will NOT work on a legacy BIOS (non-UEFI)
Customer Review:
Note: I rated this 4 stars based on other reviews. I could not actually test out the product, since it wasn't compatible with my system, and and I did not want to give them a 1 star.

Check your motherboard BIOS before ordering this product. For HP computers, if it's 2011 or older, there is a good chance that it is a legacy BIOS, and will not have the option to switch from an internal graphics card, to a dedicated graphics card. I had to return this item, for that reason.

Graphics card installed fine, but PC would not boot pass startup screen. Could not even access the BIOS menu.
Once the card was removed, the PC booted normally.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Works in a 1U Supermicro with 200w Power Supply
Customer Review: I wanted something to do Handbrake h264 NVenc encoding for video in a Supermicro 1U server. This just fits with the riser card. Runs at 39-40c and works great under Fedora 33 Linux. Beware - there are two cards. I bought the one on the left for another machine. It has a fan and is great. I hit the order another and got the one on the right. It doesn't have VGA or Display port. The heat sink one runs too hot and will not work in the 1U server. Ensure you get the fan one. They shipped the wrong one. After exchanging it now resides in my 1U and encodes many video files and is so much better than the Matrox VGA onboard card. It has low voltage draw and works with the 200w power supply in the server. Also works great in an HPE-1360t as a replacement for the nVidia 630 which burned out after 7 years.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Good for A Server, Not Gaming
Customer Review:
I bought this product nearly a year ago and I just got around to reviewing it, due to upgrading my motherboard and CPU this month. I basically threw this card in, got driver's and just left it in the system for a year.
A few things to note, one this is a low profile card that seems to be meant to be put in to a server like setup, and not for gaming purposes. The second thing to note is that this card is actually a PCI-E x8 card, not a PCI-E x16 card as it's currently labeled as. On top of that the specs are also listed incorrectly, the clock core is around 800mhz, not the listed 950mhz, the GPU ram speed is also listed about 100mhz above what it actually runs at. This card does state it supports DirectX 12, which is semi true, however it only seems to actually utilize DirectX 11 and seems to almost emulate DirectX 12 compatibility.
Other than that the card is perfect for light YouTube/ web browsing, or really old game's from around 2003 and below.
The card can be semi overcocked, but don't expect to get much more then what it runs at out of the box.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Perfect upgrade for legacy Linux terminal
Customer Review:
Linux, regardless of distro, has pros & cons like anything else. As any long time user knows drivers can be a source of frustration (thankfully that's gotten much better in recent years).

With support for an older integrated chipset dropped in current versions I was unable to upgrade an otherwise suitable machine. This was a simple drop in solution that was immediately identified and supported everything needed for a 1080p display with Kubuntu Cosmic.

If you're looking at this card you're not looking for 4k, gaming, or high performance. You're looking for functional upgrade for functional older equipment. Reliable product from a trusted manufacturer at a reasonable price. This will be my go-to solution for any such need while available.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
My Nvidia P1310 graphics card got zapped through a thunderstorm. I ordered a Geoforce 710 to replace it. Initially, the 710 card was not recognized by my system (Dell XPS 8500). After a few reboots, it was finally recognized and the driver got installed. After a half-hour operation, the screen got snowy and the system hung, requiring a reboot. It happened several times. I have taken the board out and am using the builtin display interface until I get a different graphics card.

Nvidia is a reputable name in this area. I am not sure why this was happening. Either the card was bad or maybe the 710 power needs are more than my power supply can handle. But that is unlikely in a big desktop system.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Great upgrade for Gateway/Acer SX2110G-UW23 SFF (Purchased 2013)
Customer Review:
Read all the reviews and was concerned about compatibility but this video card was the only one that appeared to fit the specifications for the Acer small SFF fit.
Observations: used in a Windows 10 Build 1909 desktop. All security and cumulative updates installed. Many reviews (here and other sites) said that the card was not Windows 10 compatible. I purchased and installed to see what would “really” happen. Boot process was nominal but slow due to the hard wired AMD 45 Series Dual Core E1-1500 APU (CPU/GPU combo) on the motherboard and the installation of the generic Windows 10 driver updates. Once it finished loading the Windows 10 Basic Video Driver (2006 version), the computer stabilized nicely and performed within MB specifications (it’s most definitely NOT a gaming rig). The video card also fixed a persistent onboard GPU heat stress problem (95° C/197° F) that used only a passive heat sink (I had previously pulled the sink, applied new thermal paste with absolutely no improvement) by automatically disabling the onboard GPU and automatically enabling the PCIe 2.0 x16 expansion slot as I’d hoped and expected. Then I loaded the latest Nvidia driver for GeForce GT 710 2G3D LP series cards (with fan) from the Nvidia website (per the MSI website directions). There was absolutely no problems installing & running the 64-bit version of the driver. I also updated the Windows 10 basic video driver (2019 version) as backup (for MB GPU; no plans to use it unless there is a catastrophic failure of the MSI card).
Conclusion and recommendation: Another quality product from MSI. Don't hesitate to use this card on older desktops that have an onboard fixed GPU as a viable upgrade solution. The low profile (LP) kit comes with the pictured default standard full height bracket (4.2 inches). There are also two LP brackets (3.118 inches) that can be substituted (like I did) requiring two LP slots if you need to use the VGA 15-pin socket. The Dual-link DVI and HDMI connectors are paired to the primary bracket; the VGA connector tied via the ribbon cable to the video card board and is secured on the second bracket using the existing video plug female fasteners. I did not test the DVI or HDMI connectors as the monitor my client uses is VGA only, so I can't comment on usability/compatibility or any issues that may occur.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Not Compatible with BiOS before 2011 for Dual Monitor Function.
Customer Review:
Bought for “Split Screen” function for Dual Monitors.
Pros: Build quality is superior. Easy to install. Comes with extra expansion slot covers. Cons: it worked for 2-3 days without any software install. Then windows 10 crashed and got stuck in reboot mode. Spoke to Nvidia support, they suggested that I clear out “possibly” faulty software and do a complete reinstall. That didn’t work, computer screen continued to flicker and random shut downs continued. Someone suggested my power supply might not be sufficient. I checked my PC, it had 350W power supply. This was purchased for Dell Studio 540 with Intel Core 2 Quad 8300 processor. Turns out the BiOS is from 2009. This card won’t function with bios from 2011 or before. I have no use for the card, I removed it and my PC works great, but I don’t have Dual Monitor function anymore.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Replaced old GE Force 8300 and was cheaper
Customer Review:
1. Replaced old GPU on old rig that I built in 2015 - if it ain't broke

2. Works right outta the box but missing driver cd so it will fudge up your display set up until drivers are downloaded which you have to go online for - this was not fun but whatevs

3. So far works great and haven't had a blue screen of death so far since old gpu fan stopped working and I couldn't find a new fan replacement - just changed the whole darn thing out.

4. I also used IObit driver booster pro to update all drivers on rig in case there is a hardware/software glitch conflict which causes issues in the future - preemptive but yolo

Overall good for the price - the missing driver cd was a pain in the a$$

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
I'm not a gamer nor a graphics artist. I use my PC to maintain two web sites, watch movies, television and listen to music. I needed HDMI video output to feed my monitor which my PC's motherboard did not provide. So I was looking for an inexpensive video card. Not only was this video card among the most inexpensive it was made by the same company as my motherboard, MSI. The other thing I liked about the card is that unlike other video cards it used no cooling fan. It used a large heat sink. Thus, keeping he noise level down.

With all MSI products, the build quality is excellent and beyond reproach. I strongly suggest this card if you only need a light duty graphics card.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Works great most of the time but blacks out on transitions
Customer Review: I don't game on my PC. I just needed a card which would handle my 2560x1440 monitor. This claims to do that, but it doesn't quite. When I open windows which cause a large white area to suddenly appear the whole display goes dark for a couple of seconds, then recovers. I see on the internet that others have experienced the same issue. I tried all the solutions suggested and some improved the situation but none cured it. Finally the card started to show lines on the display and little floaters. I knew its days were numbered. I looked again and this card still looked like the best option. Maybe I got a lemon? There was a newer model. So I bought the newer one and it still blacks out, although much less. So far nothing else has gone wrong.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Enabling 4K Video Monitor (but poor Linux support)
Customer Review:
I am not using this for gaming ... I moved to a 4K TV as a monitor (Oh wow what a game changer) and needed to add a video card to support it. Just like having 4 monitors but without the mechanical borders around the screens. Instead of 40 lines, I can now have 90 lines of code up at once (and have two columns of code and one column of board schematics and layout). My work system seems archaic compared to my home system now. This video card has performed very well.
I had to reinstall the software a couple of times (which is a very manual process) and on advice switched to AMD Radeon series which is fully supported with the default Fedora Linux install.
Nothing wrong with the GT 710 hardware, just the software support is poor so I am down-grading my rating.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Very low power consumption, decent graphics, but has problems on Linux
Customer Review:
This GPU appears to have compatibility issues with Linux, at least with OpenSUSE Leap 42.3 and 15.0. I didn't have time to test it on any other Linux distro's.

I bought this for a server running OpenSUSE Linux Leap 42.3, but I had regular problems with either the system completely crashing or the mouse and keyboard freezing while the system kept running. I tried installing Nvidia proprietary drivers to replace the default drivers, but I still had problems.

I've been using Nvidia GPU's on older OpenSUSE servers for nearly a decade without a problem. The problem appears to me to be an incompatibility with current OpenSUSE versions rather than a defect in the card itself, because when I tested it by installing OpenSUSE Leap 15.0 (which is newer than Leap 42.3, despite the numbering), the install process gave me a warning that the card was incompatible.

I was happy with this GPU other than the crashing and freezing. Graphic quality was good for such a cheap card - though I'm not sure how great it would be for gaming - and the power draw was very low. I tested it with a Kill-A-Watt meter and the system's power consumption over four hours was exactly the same as with the Asus P9D-E 4L motherboard's integrated graphics.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
We were newbies to installing video cards. This is a half size card but the card comes with the full size plate installed. In the box were two half-sized plates. You'll need to unscrew the full sized plate (4 screws, can be untwisted with a flat nose plier) and then attach the two plates (one for the HDMI and the slot next to it, one for the VGA port) to the card. Then voila, it can be installed easily.

The card works great. Tested with some Steam games, the framerate and resolution is very much improved.

Remember to go to the nvdia website and download the latest drivers and optimize the drivers for games if you have any running.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Would love to actually use this one but can't, no drivers included and nvidia doesn't recog card
Customer Review:
Got this to use with 3 monitors for a work machine. When I got the card the package wasn't sealed and it wasn't even in an Amazon box, just a shipping label slapped on the product box with no seal.

Inside there were no brackets, no manual and no driver disk. Card was in the static bag though and since I needed this thing for work, I tossed it into the computer and went and downloaded the Nvidia drivers that the MSI website says to get.

Welp, drivers don't recognize the card. I've now tried 3 different versions to get this thing to work and now it's coming out of the computer, going back into the box and going back to amazon.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: Purchased this for its very low wattage/power consumption 20w max usage, on a low power supply sff desktop computer situation. Has a nice H.D.1440p video playback though not good for 4k. I game with some older games pre 2010 and work ok on this ddr3 version , they claim 30 to 40 percent better performance on ddr5 version but has higher wattage draw and did not want to risk it not working for my situation. All in all a good affordable basic multimedia and office computing card.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Works well in Dell Optiplex 9020 SFF computer, but reconfig of rear connector brackets required.
Customer Review: My video card came with the full height rear connector metal bracket installed. The card itself fits into the PCI-e motherboard connector, but this rear connector bracket extends beyond the computer's chassis. Use the two half-height rear connector metal brackets (included) for Small Form Factor computers instead. My card came with two half-height metal connector brackets; one for the hdmi and dvi connector, and the second for the vga connector. I removed the default full height metal connector bracket from the video card, (this bracket uses 3 connectors; dvi, hdmi, and vga). I installed the hdmi/dvi bracket on the video card and I rerouted the card's VGA cable and connector to the adjacent rear connector slot using the 2nd half height metal bracket. Booted computer and loaded the Nvidia drivers, then shut-down and I disconnected the vga cable and installed a hdmi cable between the video card and monitor. Computer then came up fine on the hdmi connection. I'm using it now to write this review. And this great priced video card sure beats the computers embedded video controller! Thank-you!

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
This is not, nor has it ever been, a gaming card. It IS, however, a great general-purpose card and a nice upgrade from older onboard graphics that are quickly becoming unsupported by Windows 10. This is the low end go-to card for quick upgrades when you want dual monitors and such to use with home computing or light business work. With DDR3 and 1-2GB of RAM this card will bottleneck on games quickly.

Our repair shop builds custom gaming computers and does upgrades on older machines and has for 20 years. Although this card is good for what it is, at the price it is, it should not be featured as a gaming card.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Will cause frustrating sound and microphone problems
Customer Review:
I'm not much of a gamer but wanted to upgrade my PC to be able to handle the few I happen to play with friends online. I didn't need anything too fancy, so this card seemed perfect. For video purposes, it absolutely is! Not only does my PC not crash almost everytime I try to play a more resource-heavy game now (it actually doesn't crash at all anymore), but I can actually up the video settings to the highest levels in the games I actually do play.

The reason I only gave it 2 stars is due to the severe sound problems this card causes. I spent days going through various forums and trouble shooting processes to get my microphone to work again and it just won't anymore. Somehow this card makes my computer unable to even recognize my microphone now. Not only that, but sound in general has become an issue. Many times when I open a game or other app, there is no sound. I have to unplug my hdmi cord until the sound comes back and when I plug it back in, sometimes it stays on, sometimes it doesn't. Sometimes it doesn't come on at all. Sometimes it works just fine. Very frustrating. Again, I spent several days and frustrating hours trying to fix this but could find nothing. If you have a degree in IT, maybe you could figure it out. If you do, please let me know!

I would have given this card only 1 star, but since it did indeed fix the video problems and the sound does work sometimes, I wanted to give it at least 2 stars, but I really used my microphone a lot so the fact that I can no longer use it really annoys me.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Great price for a good card
Customer Review: It's not going to be a cutting-edge video experience on the now-ancient PCIe bus... But for a mere $40, this does a great job at squeezing the last bit of life out of old motherboards. It's small and installs easily -- no auxiliary power connections needed. No complications with drivers under Ubuntu Linux, I can't speak for Windows but I assume drivers for this chipset are a well-solved problem. It drives my new 2560x1440 monitor without problems, the reason for my purchase, and I'm very pleased with it.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
Got this for a refurbished Dell Optiplex 9010 MiniTower for one of my grandkids and it wasn't quite 'Plug-n-Play' with Windows 10. There's no driver disk included in the box, so you'd think it would be, but when I installed it I could only get a signal from the VGA port. I got nothng from the HDMI port.

Searching around for a solution, I found mention of being sure to have the latest driver when using the card with Windows 10. Further searching led to a site with the latest NVDIA driver for the card and downloaded it and promptly discovered you have to install the driver before installing the card. Once the driver and card were installed, the HDMI port worked perfectly.

A driver disk is included with the MSI GeForce 210 card. How hard would it have been to include one with the 710 card to avoid the frustration?

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: works with windows 10 signed drivers, for now anyway
Customer Review: I gave my son my old gaming machine and windows 10 no longer supports unsigned drivers. It was a 4GB radeon, and we got this just to make the PC work since we had to re-install windows. The old card is fine, but not supported by windows 10 due to the new drivers signing requirement I think from 8 and I didn't feel like trying to re-install windows 7 to make them work. This driver does has signed drivers though it was a pain in the butt to get the proper drivers they do work. They don't seem to have native support but you can get them and they work. This only applies to folks who need the "real" drivers for gaming. The old card worked ok with the default drivers windows supplies, but not for gaming.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Not For Gaming, But Great For a Old Machine
Customer Review: Bought two of these. Easy Peazy. Installed in 10 minutes. Downloaded the latest drivers. It kept my old embedded GPU (Intel) settings. Back up and running. Very happy. I have two old Lenovo desktops. Probably 7+ years old. Not used for gaming, but the new card benchmarked 50% better than the on-board Intel CPU graphics. And 300% better on FPS. (FPS is still not very good, but better is better...) The on-board Intel graphics are way out of date. I use these machines for video encoding and decoding programs which can use GPU acceleration. I expect improved performance. (BTW, if you have a late-model machine (<3 years old) don't bother with these cards. The on-board graphics are better, but they can bring new-life to an old machine.)

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review: They claim it's 2.7 inches yet it's nearly 3.5 and this won't fit in my machine, thanks for lying and taking my money

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Excellent Video Card for our older PC
Customer Review: We bought this to get access to OpenGL support on our older Dell PC. The integrated graphics weren't cutting it. This card dropped right into the PCI Express x16 (1.1) slot and worked perfectly. There's no fan to make noise and it doesn't draw much power. Windows 10 downloaded and installed drivers and we updated those with the latest nVidia drivers. I connected this to a new LG 4K monitor and it works beautifully. I expect that we will be able to view some 4K HDR streaming content soon. I will update this review once we've checked out the performance of this card with some 4K HDR streaming content.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Great nearly 4K resolution upgrade for older computers.
Customer Review: I am not a gamer but wanted higher monitor resolution for XL spreadsheet work. This video card with 1GB memory allowed me to raise the resolution from 1080P (1920 x 1080) to nearly 4K (3840 x 2160). I had problems raising it to full 4K (4096 x 2160) with some of the spreadsheet cells intermittently turning black and then returning to normal with pgup/pgdn. I do not know if the problem is insufficient memory or the change in aspect ratio (3840 is exactly double 1920 as 2160 is 1080). In any event, the loss of 256 pixels (6%) at the lower resolution is not enough to worry about. I am very pleased with this video card installation.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Works great! for the price it's good
Customer Review: I think what everyone needs to understand and what graphics card manufacturers need to educate a lot of people on are that graphics card are NOT going to fix everything. Your ram, hard drive, etc will all take into effect with how it synergies with a graphics card. If you put this card in an old computer dont expect it to be 5x faster. With that said, I have a dell xps 8500 purchased in 2012. All this time I have had to play games on lowest of settings, turning pretty much everything off in my display settings ( vertical sync, shadowing etc. etc. etc.) which played smoothly but with LOW LOW settings on my old graphics card. My computer has 24 gig ram so more than enough memory. I've had an AMD radeon 7500 64mb ( it says that but when I look it up its 1gb on computer?) not sure but regardless I thought to myself I needed an upgrade in graphics card (obviously) and because it has been so long and I didn't want to spend too much money. So I bought this card. After popping it in my computer, my computer restarted a couple times after I started it up, went onto nvidia.com and installed the graphics driver without issues. Fan ran well on the graphics card. I tested it on call of duty which i played, left 4 dead 2 on high settings without any issues and other games on high settings. It's pretty incredible how I can actually play on high settings smoothly!!! For the price I think it's great and works well. how long it lasts? don't know about that yet. But so far so good. All in all, if you have a computer with enough ram i think this will be good to buy as it should probably play all games without any issues

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Solid card for productivity on modest workstation
Customer Review:
I ordered this card to place in a used Optiplex 7010 MT, as an upgrade over the integrated Intel graphics. The card fits nicely and the power draw is no problem for the stock Dell power supply. This model is fanless and will emit some heat, so make sure your case fans are adequate. Video quality is more than sufficient for daily work and productivity, streaming videos, and watching movies fullscreen at 1920x1080. I don't do any gaming so I can't rate its utility there.

After installing this card, text was initially being rendered very blurry with visible red artifacts. I had to invest a lot of effort into fixing the Windows ClearType settings to make text readable without getting a headache. This wasn't an issue with the integrated Intel graphics or with a Radeon card I had laying around. It may be something specific to the Nvidia drivers. The time I spent resolving this problem dropped my rating down to a 4; otherwise, this card is a great pairing for the Optiplex 7010 MT.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Do yourself a favor and do not buy this
Customer Review: As other reviewers have mentioned this controller looks good. The design is sleek and if you have an MSI gaming laptop or desktop rig it would seem to make sense to get an MSI controller. However, this controller will let you down. I've used this controller off and on for a few months and noticed the left thumbstick drifts and seems to be off-centered with no way that I can find to recalibrate it. More importantly, however, about 2 weeks ago the controller simply stopped connecting to my MSI laptop and an Android tablet. Do yourself a favor and spend a little extra or something like an Xbox controller.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: What an amazing price for the performance
Customer Review: I've only put about 12 hours on it so far, but not 1 issue setting up and using it yet. What an amazing price for the performance! Makes a huge difference on my gateway sx2185-ur24 from the integrated graphics processing. Swapping the faceplate for the included slimlines was easy. It went into the socket perfectly and sits firm. Booted up immediately and was easy to install the control software to optimize the settings for my individual games with the profile options. Stays nice and cool, too! Processor runs at the same temp as before. My 5 stars means I got more than I was expecting, way more with this one.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: If you don't have a graphics card at all, or need a cheap way to have multiple monitors...
Customer Review: This isn't a high end gaming graphics card, let's make that clear right now. But I've helped hundreds of people have multiple monitors or get started by pointing them to this graphics card. It's a good way to set up a secondary monitor for cheap, if you only have an integrated card it's also better than that and very easy to install. Legitimately there are better cards that can do the gaming job, but if you want one that does 2 jobs in one, then you can't sneeze at it.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Great Replacement Video Card for Windows 10 Creator Upgrade
Customer Review: I have a 6 year of Dell Studio XPS desktop that came with a ATI HD5570 video card which was no longer supported for driver upgrade since 2015 by AMD. Windows 10 Creator upgrade would not work with old card (Black screen of death) so I replaced it the this GT 710 and Windows 10 loaded the new driver and the Windows 10 Creator upgrade went in with no issues.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Used for HP 8300 Small Form Desktop
Customer Review: Integrated graphics burned out, so needed a video card. HP 8300 small form refurbished machine with Windows 10 Professional. Quick plug and play, no issues. Graphics much better as this card has an HDMI output and computer did not come with one. Do not game on this computer, so I do not know how it performs for that, but works well with video and photos and browser.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
Works perfectly. I'm not a gamer running heavy graphics so I can't attest to how this card performs in that respect. What I really needed the card for was Windows 10 stopped supporting the card I've been using for the past several years. I was getting funky driver and display problems because Windows was installing their display driver and I had to jump through hoops to get the old one working (ATI stopped making drivers for it after 2012) after every major Windows 10 update. Along with that, there were random BSOD Video TDR Failures (because of the smaller updates).

I don't need a super duper fast graphics rendering or massive memory, so I went with this card. The price was right and most of my electronics are refurbs anyway. As long as it works, I'm happy.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Low profile 2gb with fan no issues
Customer Review:
Everyone is a gaming critique give me z break lol... Anywho, this baby here for 50$ can play most games from low to medium settings in my case with a i5 3.1 processor it runs flawlessly. Sure some games may require you to run on low settings but for 50$ show me a better card ill wait👀.... My partucular model is the 2gb with a fan amd it has had no issues months in using it almost everday. This is my first time dabbling in video cards and I'm amazed at how well even youtube looks now apparently anything plAying media upgrades in quality with your card? Amazing performance so far I dont make enough to throw down a few hundred for the card i want so this will do fine for now call it "entry level"
Also i did have to download quite a bit of driver software off the sites but my pc recognized the card immediately.

GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review:
Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
 Not sure if I ran into a compatibility issue or a fault card but this card is causing so weird issues. For starters I get artifacts in the form on red lines all over my screen and when using a monitor via HDMI the BIOS setup page on my motherboard is in Japanese when set to English..... I had to dig out an ancient VGA monitor... it’s crazy. I am using this as part of a new build. The motherboard is an MSI product and the CPU is a Ryzen 5 2600. GPU Name: MSI Gaming GeForce GT 710 2GB GDRR3 64-bit HDCP Support DirectX 12 OpenGL 4.5 Single Fan Low Profile Graphics Card (GT 710 2GD3 LP)
Customer Review Title: Does what it's meant to do and more
Customer Review:
Bought this card because I recently decided to build a pc and needed a graphics card for output (waiting until Holiday sales for a higher end GPU), set up was fairly easy even though it is my first pc build ever! Only supported a square screen on my widescreen monitor until I updated Windows and when I tried too update to the official drivers it would only output a green screen, so I have yet to update them, but it is working fine only occasional stutters when running multiple tasks as it only has 1 gb of RAM! Definitely going to keep this thing around in case I ever build another pc and need a display output!
Pros:
-Cheap
-Works for basic computing/media
-Surprisingly can run LoL at 60+ fps (Medium settings) depending on the rest of your system.
Cons:
