GPU Name: PNY Quadro P400 Graphic Card
Customer Review Title: tremendous speed improvement in video encoding
Customer Review:
Purchased this for one reason only: hardware encoding of videos. Pain in the southern most region to work out the ffmpeg commands to accomplish the task but once done there was a tremendous speed improvement. FYI:
=============
# create a 'HWtranscode' function
function HWtranscode () {
for f in *.ts;
# nividia hardware transcoding
do ffmpeg -hwaccel cuvid -i "$f" -vcodec h264_nvenc -profile:v 2 -g 30 -qp 26 -c:a ac3 "${f%.ts}.mp4";
done
}
=============

As for its use as display card: Is seems adequate to drive my two dell 24 inch monitors. I can not detect any other particular improvements. The tiny dongles it requires are a also a pain in the most southern region.

Update September 2018:
No problems and I occasionally use it to drive a 42 Inch Visio TV TV as well as the two Dell computer monitor.
I note someone commented about the quality of the video encoding. That is controlled by the encoding parameters. You can anything from low quality and high speed to high quality and low speed. I tried for something in the middle.

These are the cables that I am using. I needed a 10 foot and a six foot cable. These work and are relative thin. I tried some others that did NOT work.
DP to DVI Cord 10ft Computer Video Cable for Laptop to TV or Projector 2 Pack - Black

GPU Name: PNY Quadro P400 Graphic Card
Customer Review: Good product but you cannot use all three video outputs simultaneously. The max is two at once.

GPU Name: PNY Quadro P400 Graphic Card
Customer Review: Purchased this card to encode HD streams in Plex. What a difference after installing the card. No more pegging the CPU.

GPU Name: PNY Quadro P400 Graphic Card
Customer Review Title: Driver install in a Linux environment is unorthodox
Customer Review: Installed this board for CAD under Ubuntu 18LTS. The UBUNTU drivers for the board don't work properly, so you have to use the Nvidia drivers. Nvidia's install script leaves a lot to be desired. It works, but isn't obvious. It also doesn't update the /etc/default/grub file so if you happen to change it, the driver disappears and you're left at 640x480. Reinstalling the driver solves the issue, but Nvidia should update the system files so that changing Grub doesn't clobber their driver.

GPU Name: PNY Quadro P400 Graphic Card
Customer Review Title: Works with Ubuntu 20.04 and Nvida Driver 440.64
Customer Review:
I bought this (VCQP400-PB) card to replace an AMD V7900 that died. I'm using it in Dell T5500 workstation with 3 monitors, two in landscape and one in portrait mode. All three monitors are attached using DisplayPort cables. The card is small, so I had to use the included taller bracket to install. The card is short in length and in height.

The card is low power and doesn't require the use of an extra 6/8 pin power cable.

The card does support 3 monitors simultaneously. Also, the card came with three miniDP to DP adapters, even though they're not shown in the V1 pictures. As I write this only the pictures for the V2 version show the adapters. I would preferred not to have to use adapters, but I would have to buy a much more expensive card to get standard DisplayPort connectors. The mini connectors do lock into the back, so except for reliability problems associated with more connections, I expect these will work OK.

The only problem I had with installation was getting the portrait monitor to work. The Ubuntu display settings tool just wouldn't work with the portrait monitor. It either turned the monitor off or left it in landscape mode. I solved the problem by using the Nvidia X Server Settings tool.

I'm not a gamer, so I can't speak to performance there, but playback in Kdenlive (a non-linear video editor) was smoother than with the AMD card. HTML5 rendering in browsers also seems a bit faster.

Amazon was the vendor. No problems with the shipping or packaging.

GPU Name: PNY Quadro P400 Graphic Card
Customer Review Title: jury is still out on this card
Customer Review: This is my second card. It is just what i need: to run three large monitors for the office. Not for gaming. Every now and then, I hit a day when one monitor acts up. Flashes on and off for one second, and then on for 30 seconds. I have replaced the cables, switcheed monitors. Some days, no issues. I would get a different card, but I don't need a $800 liquid cooled gaming card. I might try the P620. Or maybe replace the cables again. Who knows. every manufacturer blames the other. It is great when it works at 100%, I run three large Dell monitors at UHD, so just less than 4K

Customer Review Title: It’s a solid high performance card, and I’ve bought a lot of them!
Customer Review:
We use these Quadro P400s in high-performance mail insertion (letter-folding, envelope stuffing) machines that we build, and so far I have purchased and shipped 18 cards.
We run the control system display in one, diagnostic and log output in the second monitor, and a high performance vision system output in the third.
I have only had a problem with one of the cards after about a year, apparently due to a dirty/dusty installation environment (Think about it... your average sheets of office/laser printer paper generates scads of tiny dust particles. And picking, folding and stuffing 7 to 15 sheets of paper, at a rate of up to 15,000 envelopes an hour, gets to be a very dusty business. Factor in that your average insurance company like Geico is shipping out well over 2 million envelopes a week, and you get a LOT of electrostatically attracted dust!)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
UPDATED.

Wow. So, first I’m going to fill you in on what I’m using so you can make the call yourself.

Dell Optiplex 990
I5-2500 3.3Ghz
Windows 7 Professional 64 bit
16GB memory ( 4x4gb 10600 1333mhz sticks- all same brand/model)
250gb HD
Lenovo 24” monitor 1080p

Upgraded from a 2gig ddr3 card and wow what a difference. I have yet to play a game that I couldn’t max out the graphics settings! This GPU isn’t all that loud, I only hear it becaus I have my case open. The OC option is great, it gives it a nice bump, but haven’t really had to use it unless I wanted to feel spoiled. I’m new to gaming and people say this is a mid range card, but to be honest it pushes out WAY more crisp graphics than my x box one S. The responsiveness is also great. I have yet to see the GPU clock higher than 60C even when the OC option is on. I don’t see a reason for the $1k graphics cards too be honest. This has shown all the power I need! Not to mention it is running on the motherboard and stock power supply of 250 something!

Game played with ultra/max settings.

The Witcher 3
FIFA 18
Endless Space 2
Metal Gear Solid 5 phantom pain
Arkham Knight GOTY edition
Far cry primal

GTA 5 on mix of medium/high
GR Wildlands on high/ultra (using OC with some tweaks in bios) even though some features load slow ie. terrain

Edited to add some games I’ve played on this card since I bought it.

-----------------------------------------------------
UPDATE:

So when I first got this card I was a bit of a newbie when it came to gaming. This card is still a very good card! If your worried about FPS, I'm sorry, unless you have a beefy system with matching ddr5 memory to add as vram to the card, you won;t get it. The above games I was playing at lower resolutions, with higher settings. I was originally playing with the stock PSU on my pc, but have upgraded recently to 550W PSU. It has made this decent card into a better performing card! With the new PSU I was able to push the card a lot harder when I overclock and it did make a huge difference in how fast the images were rendered in game. The current games I play are below:

These unlike the last review are all on full screen 1080p.

Ghost Recon: Wildands --- Mostly medium settings with ultra texture levels. Average:35-42 FPS
FrostPunk: ALL Ultra settings ---- 40 FPS almost constantly
FIFA 18: Ultra/Max settings ---- 50 FPS plus
Sims 4---Ultra/Max everything-- does it really matter? lol its Sims. Walk in the park even without overclocking.
Fallout 4 GOTY-----High/Ultra mix -- without MODS in game it did well 45-55 FPS, with mods about 35
Batman: Arkham Origins- Max settings 50-55fps
Witcher 3---Mostly Ultra but with a few off or on low---45-50 fps
Splinter Cell:Blacklist-------Ultra preset in game ----50 FPS
This War of Mine-----Ultra Settings----40-45fps
MGS V----Ultra Settings 50 fps SOLID\

The card I think with a strong PSU can take on MUCH more than it can with a stock PSU. I thought about upgrading to the 1060 for future proofing, but I just can't seem to justify it yet :)

Even with only 2 GB VRAM on the card, this this is handling what I throw at it well.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Decent graphics card that fits a HP 570 Series Pavilion PC!
Customer Review:
*This review is for the Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)*
I bought a small form factor HP 570-p064 (for $400) to be used for general, non-gaming use, but soon after I decided to upgrade the power supply and get the best graphics card that could fit in its cramped case. After hours of research, I found that the only card that would reasonably fit would be the Gigabyte GT 1030 -- a very flat, 2 GB GDDR5 card -- and I ordered it from Amazon for about $95.

So, I installed an EVGA uATX power supply and the card...But after less than a week of playing some old Steam games and demos, I was disappointed by how much it did not improve upon the integrated Intel HD 630 graphics. I believe I needed a 4 GB video card, although they were twice the size; it would be a miracle to find something that would work in a HP 570.

I just couldn't believe the GT 1030 could be the only option, but the PCI-E port is flanked by a power supply and a slimline DVD player. In addition, the motherboard's two yellow audio inputs are partially blocking the top graphics card slot -- a weird design choice. So, the prospect of installing any dual-slot, 4GB card would be limited by card length, height, and "shape": Basically, any "blocky" cards (like some of the EVGA models) longer than 6.8 inches would not work.

I thought that maybe this Gigabyte model would work, trying to measure and imagine it in my case. Well, I was lucky enough to find an obscure review from another HP 570 series purchaser (on another seller's website) who wrote that the Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti Low Profile graphics card "barley fit." It seemed that the length and height would be OK, and the sides might just perfectly angle near the front of the card to allow just enough space to clear the motherboard's audio inputs.

Well, I chatted with Amazon about the situation and they took care of anything -- FIVE STARS for customer service! They sent me a new 1050 Ti graphics card via free one-day shipping, and they said there would be no penalty if the card didn't fit. And they helped me return the GT 1030. Thank you Amazon once again!

I was very happy when my new GPU installed perfectly, and I got started sampling some games.

My HP 570-p064 only has an Intel i3 dual-core 7100 3.9GHZ processor with 8 GB DDR4 RAM. Windows 10 64-bit is on an SSD, and my games are installed on a 1 TB hard drive. I am limited to a 23" 1080p 60 Hz monitor. Here are some of my in-game FPS results with the Gigabyte 1050 Ti OC -- with some slight overclocking -- using 1080p resolution:

- Grand Theft Auto V with high settings and some effects: 50-60 FPS average
- Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition with high settings: 60 FPS
- Final Fantasy: A Realm Reborn with high settings and high effects: 60 FPS
- Max Payne 3 with very high settings and high effects: 60 FPS
- Doom (2016) with max resolution and medium effects: 60 FPS
- Spec Ops: The Line (demo) with the highest settings: a solid 60 FPS
- Skyrim with ultra settings running high definition textures: 60 FPS

I hope this review helps anyone with an HP 570 series computer make a sizable graphics card upgrade. Although it's more of a casual gaming card, I believe it can play games on par -- or better in many cases -- than a regular PS4. Your success will largely depend on your processor, too, and I have an average Intel unit.

Please note you'll need a new power supply as this card draws 70 watts, and the stock 180-watt power supply will not work safely, if at all. I recommend the EVGA 500 watt White model. And if someone finds an even better GPU that fits an HP 570, please let the world know.

Customer Review Title: RGB works fine as long as you're not plugging it into a ...

Plugged in, no problems. Fans and temps, no problems. Does exactly what it's supposed to do plus some for a measly 1050 since it's Gigabyte overclocked. But remember, CPU has a big impact on your FPS performance, as well. So don't judge my frames just based off of the fact that I have this card (the 1050 G1 Gaming 2GB). I have an i5-7600k paired with this 1050.

1920x1080 jenky 60hz monitor;
CS: GO - Average 300 frames on tweaked medium/high graphic settings
PUBG - 60-100 FPS tweaked graphics settings
H1Z1 - A very stable 90 fps (just got it, may have capped fps setting somewhere i don't know about)

Anyway, you get the jist. I got it for ~$40 less than it's listed at right now; so I'm definitely satisfied. Cheap and great for casual performance. 4 stars simply because of the inherent product quality, (it's just a 1050), and the fact that it's gone up ~$40. Would have given it 5 stars because of the great value to performance if it was still sitting at the cheaper price!

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
I refurbish computers in my free time and lately I've been getting requests to upgrade my computers into entry level gaming computers.

The first card I purchased was a GeForce GT1030 2G, but only because the size of the computer didn't allow for a larger card. Then, I purchased the GT1050 Ti to test for upcoming builds and I was pleasantly surprised.

Let's get one big thing out of the way. This card is not top of the line and is not intended for serious gamers. Having said that, for beginners or someone that needs a decent upgrade from an integrated graphics card then this card is what I recommend.

I play a decent amount of Civilization V and City Skylines. On medium settings I'm averaging roughly 50 fps. Granted, I have a 500gb SSD, 1TB HDD and 16GB Corsair Vengeance Pro RAM with an i5 processor. So, if you have less memory or a slower processor you may not get the same results. I'm betting if I doubled my RAM I could probably squeak out a bit more fps.

Seriously, if you're a newbie to gaming or just want an affordable upgrade to your current graphics, I recommend you take a look at this card. It does NOT require additional power and I run my card through a Dell desktop. Anyone that knows Dell computers knows that their PSUs don't have that much juice. However, after upgrading to a EVGA 600w PSU today, my fps went up slightly to around 55fps.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Great low profile card that performs very well!
Customer Review:
I bought this for my HP Compaq Elite 8300 SFF that I bought a couple of years ago because I wanted a "gaming" machine and the Intel HD 2500 integrated graphics isn't exactly great. The only thing that I didn't like was that I was sent an email after purchase for the "Fortnite Bundle" and while I don't play it, I thought I'd give it a try after redeeming the code they sent me....Well...the code had already been redeemed and Nvidia told me the email that redeemed it and it looked to be a Russian email that had redeemed it weeks before I even purchased this. They kept transferring me back and forth over 10 times and basically told me to contact "the developer" which I asked them to clarify and they said to contact Gigabyte. I did THAT and was told to contact Amazon or Nvidia. So that was all pointless. If you're buying this for an upgrade, go for it. If you're buying this and you want the Fortnite promotion, you won't get it which is pretty scummy if you ask me.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
Bought this card so that I could connect two desktop monitors via HDMI cables. The plan was to code on one and review documents, specs on the other. Plugged into the system and powered up. Fan on Graphics card was operational, but the screens remained black for several minutes. Eventually the screens turned off due to 'No Signal'. Tried 3 different HDMI cables and the DVI cable, with no luck.

Then I got the idea to plug one of the monitors into the onboard VGA cable and verified the OS was booted. Opened the device manager and saw the card was not compatible with the Microsoft Basic Video Driver. Loaded the drivers from the CD that came with the product and all seemed good. The driver CD required a reboot to complete installation and here is where the problem began.

Upon reboot, Windows 10 crashed due to corrupted files. Rebooted twice with the same problem. Finally Windows executed the automatic recovery which removed the Video card drivers. Once I booted into Windows, I tried again, but this time I downloaded the driver straight from the Website. Upon reboot, Windows reported corrupted files and crashed. This time, the automatic recovery program could not recovery and my whole OS was corrupted. I spent a day and a half reinstalling the OS, the drivers, the updates, and all the programs I had lost on my system.

Tech support was no help. Even asked if I had the outlet plugged into the desktop and the system was powered up. I decided to just return the item to Kohl's for a refund.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Don't buy it for its false "Bonus"!
Customer Review:
I bought this card after giving it a slight edge over others due to its offer of a free "Fortnite bundle" bonus. While the card itself is good, I've wasted an hour trying to get the bonus. I received an email from Amazon with a code and web link. I followed the link, had to give lots of personal information to create an account at GeForce, to finally get to the proper page. After entering the very long code and the "I'm not a robot" validation, it gave a cryptic message "Please use GeForce Experience 3.17 to redeem this promo code. You can download it at <redacted link at NVIDIA>. I have no idea what that is, why I need it, or why I wasn't sent there to begin with. So, I went to *that* link, downloaded it, went through a time-consuming install, which *seemed* to complete. Then I started it (but it seems to report it as an older version 3.10.x, although Add/Remove programs only shows 3.6.0.74) and (after quite a wait) it reported another useless message of "NVIDIA Installer failed" and a link for "Need help troubleshooting?"

When I go to *that* link, I get an Amazon page displaying 129 items that reference "Fortnite bundle" ... no help at all for anything related to my issue.

So, if you want a video card, consider this only as if you won't get any bonus with it. I've lost way too much time trying to get the "bonus". It's not worth it.

This GTX 1050 Ti replaced a GTX 950, and it is a huge improvement. In combination with an i5-3570K and 8gb of RAM slotted into a Gigabyte GA-Z77-D3H, I was able to maintain 60fps or more with maxed out settings on every game I tried (BF1, Overwatch, Fortnite, GTA V). Now that the mining craze has settled down, these cards are an excellent price for what they offer.

NOTE: The "Windforce OC Edition" requires a 6-pin power cable that is not included. I got mine to work just fine with a cheap 4-pin Molex to 6-pin adapter. If your PSU has no unused connectors, either buy the smaller version of the card that doesn't require the additional 6-pin connection or upgrade your PSU. If you are using an older MoBo like me, make sure to update bios or you may be stuck with a black screen after POST.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Even on a older (2009) "big box mart" computer, works great! Its a simple upgade!
Customer Review:
First off lets look what I'm using this in: A old Walmart "box" Dell Inspiron 560 computer (2009 era) with the Intel e5400 CPU; 10 Gig Ram, Win10 and stock 300 Watt power supply. This by NO means a powerhouse of a computer. With the on-board graphics being only good for the most basic of games and videos, we moved to upgrade the video to a Nvidia GT 520 (2011 era). One of the limiting factors with video cards is the power supply in the computer having enough power. Back then the GT 520 fit the bill only requiring 300W. This card worked fine until games became more graphic heavy.

Playing what would be considered "simple single and multi-player games" with my son (he has a gaming computer) was more of a aggravation then enjoyment. Games like; Flight Simulator, Spin Tires, Euro Truck Simulator, Modern Warfare 2 (all on Steam) would suffer along on only the lowest of settings.

Well this Gigabyte GeForce GTX 1050 has changed all that. Now these games are running smooth and quick. It's like having a whole new computer, even with the lacking "CPU" power. With the Video settings on High, I'm now "booking" on all my games and simulators!

The GTX 1050 requires only 300W power so no issues there. It does take the space of an extra slot in the back out your PC case, but does push right in to the board with no extra wiring. The fans are quite when the run.

I currently run two monitors, one on HDMI and one with the DVI-D (using a converter to VGA). There is a DP (display port) connector for my third monitor Ill be getting soon.

So far the only lacking is the Utility Program - kinda slow to open but does have different settings you can play this like over-clocking, fan speed, etc.

All in all, this is a great card for the price and a perfect upgrade for a older computer.

Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 2GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N1050OC-2GD)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Got the card today and working great. Installed in about 5 minutes
Customer Review:
Got the card today and working great. Installed in about 5 minutes. Probably would of installed quicker but I spent about 2 minutes looking for the pin jacks for the power supply. (someone in the Q&A said that this card (with 2 fans has to be plugged into the power supply). It doesn't. No connections anywhere on card for separate power supply connection on the card , the whole thing is powered just by sliding it into the PCI e slot. When I first installed the card and turned on PC it used a generic windows driver for about 5 minutes until windows update immediately downloaded and installed the driver from Nvida. One thing, the driver that Windows 10 pulled was pretty old and out of date so you will most certainly want to download the software and run it. I just googled the card name, took me right to their website where you can download a program from Nvida called (GeForce Experience) that will auto detect your card, and download the very latest driver, you can also select in the settings to auto update the driver as new versions come out.

Ran some stress tests on it (not very long about 10 minutes or maybe less, but temp of the card never went over 64 degrees C which is very good. Stress test is designed to push the card to the limits and if the card doesn't run super hot your in good shape. Runs at a steady 32-33 degrees in my computer when not gaming and just using internet and basic windows programs.

Overall I think this card is great value for mid range gaming on the newest games, and any of the older favorites should run at top settings. Also this card has sound drivers built in. Which kind of shocked me. My old card didn't and I was using headphones for the longest time. I was kind of shocked when all the sudden my monitor started having sound come out of it. I didn't even know my monitor had speakers built in to be honest.lol

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

Now I'm limping along with my onboard video card until I can get Gigabyte support to respond. My computer hasn't crashed or had random monitor blinking since I pulled the card out. 99% sure the card is the problem. Oh, and I did install the latest nvidia drivers from their website.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
I have a custom rig that I built myself with an AMD RYZEN 2600 and 16 gigs of ram (for now) but the one thing that I hated was the low performance video card that I was using. I upgraded from an Nvidia GeForce 730 GT (pcie 4x) to this card (which is pcie 16x) and OMG the difference is night and day. Granted, it is not "top of the line) like the rtx cards that have ray tracing, but still an amazing improvement, and for the money I definitely got a better deal than I bargained for.

The included software allows me to switch between different presets to overclock, or turn the fans either to auto or on. If I'm feeling adventurous (which I haven't yet) I can also manually adjust the clock rate and other settings (ignoring the presets).

When the game are running, they are not really noticeable. My cpu and case fans make more noise than they do.

To anyone looking to upgrade from an older pcie graphics card but not wanting to spend a ton of money, I would definitely recommend looking at this one. Definitely do some research, because this card is definitely NOT a hardcore gaming card, but it has handled every game I've thrown at it with flying pixels :P.

Only downside is that the size of the fan and orientation of the card blocks the pcie 1x slot directly under the 16x slot on my motherboard, but that's a small price to pay compared to the performance gain this card gave me.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

It seems to work for the most part at 30Hz, but it's very disturbing that I cannot get them to work. A lot of wasted $...

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Significant improvement for a reasonable price
Customer Review:
I received it promptly. The only guide that came with the card stated to insert the DVD and follow instructions on the screen. I changed the cover for the computer slot to the shorter one that came with it because my computer has a low profile case. Taking care to discharge any static on me I put the card in, inserted the DVD with drivers, ran the setup.exe file on the disc as it didn't auto-run and let it do its thing.

The screen looked weird after installing the drivers. The task bar wasn't showing up so I restarted by pressing the reset button on the computer. Both displays came up after rebooting. Regardless of this issue I think it was an easy installation and overall went well. There are two setup programs, Nvidia and Aorus Engine, that allow you to do some tweaking but I haven't changed any settings yet.

Running the PassMark performance test showed the 3D graphics rating improved from 1255 to 6421 (48th percentile to 82nd) with the card set to Gaming Mode not OC mode. Watching the test was impressive and considerably faster than with the stock graphics. The overall computer rating changed from 4126 or 80th percentile to 5353 or 94th percentile just by changing to this graphics card.

I just got it so haven't done much with it. Pictures come up instantly as I page from one to the next. I am not a gamer but have a few to try. From what I read the original graphics on my i7-8770K CPU is the integrated Intel UHD 630 which I think for general desktop use and watching videos works very well. But for graphics work or gaming this will be an improvement at a reasonable price.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Made a HUGE difference in my gaming and audio production
Customer Review:
I have an older HP tower with a good CPU (I7) but standard graphics (1 GB card), and a 320 watt power supply. I play mostly Arma 3, Planet Zoo and Planet Coaster, Civ VI. I also use my HP PC's to record, mix, master hi-res audio tracks and albums. With the standard setup video was 'passable' but really no fun at all as a gaming experience. Glitchy, slow FR, video drops, uneven play, etc...Things just took much longer to do - even my mouse clicks were affected by the catching up the video system had to do.
I always wanted to upgrade my video but I thought a larger power supply was required (at least 500 watts). I am not good enough around the PC to swap-out power supplies, so I needed to find the best video card which would work on 320 watts - and I think I found it.
The 4 GB GTX 1050 card made all the difference in the world. Immediate improvement to the point of losing sleep for playing all the time. Video is crisp, clear, and smooth. It was like playing those games for the first time - really. Just a wonderful improvement. For my music production, the DAW, instruments, and samples load faster and I can tell the machine struggles less to process 24/48 files. Very smooth and fast.
The important thing is you can probably install this yourself - even if you aren't a whiz at it (I'm not). Obviously make sure the card you choose to buy will function in your specific machine or application. It took me 15 minutes to remove the PC cover, remove old card, install new card, close cover, then download up to date drivers. As I said, this card works with 320 watts, so inspect your power supply and make sure you know what its capacity is.
Gaming is fun again. Check out the GTX 1050.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Fantastic output for gaming, but a little confusing
Customer Review:
First off, this graphics card is really good for its price. If you're like me, a layperson to PC tech and jargon, then you are just trying to find a simple explanation and review. Does this graphics card work? Yes. Is it easy to install? Yes. Will it drastically increase your gaming experience if you were using lower quality stuff before? DEFINITELY.

It's worth the investment. Now, here are some of the cons.

If you have no experience with working on the hardware of your PC, you'll definitely need instructional videos and guides. Installation is very simple (either some screws, clamps, and snap racks), but the actual "how" to get it to work can be a bit fidgety. You need to make sure you have the latest update for Nvidia drivers, otherwise it won't work- at least, mine didn't. Also, the Graphics Card comes with a CD that will install Aorus, a program that helps monitor the output of the GPU (and some other stuff). I'm not sure if it's an issue with my PC, but Aorus keeps crashing my computer. I uninstalled it, and it hasn't crashed since. Just be weary of it. My only problem with the whole ordeal is that it took me a whole day to figure out how to get this GPU running. I googled a lot, and went on forums until I finally saw someone suggest updating the drivers. The Aorus program is not entirely necessary for running your GPU, but I can see how it would be nice to see how far you're pushing the card.

Speaking of which, let's talk about the graphics performance, the main thing you'll want to know. If this is worth any consideration, with this card I was able to push previous games of mine from the lowest settings to the highest. Even the screen resolution for my PC is better thanks to the card.

Here are the main games I bought this GPU for:
1. Company of Heroes 2
2. War Thunder

In the past, my PC was barely able to run COH2 and War Thunder. It would usually crash frame rates, leaving me to play each on the lowest setting possible. I actually stopped playing PC games for a while because of this issue. I configured the GTX, and BOOM. I was able to play COH2 and War Thunder on Max settings for my screen. I've never seen these graphics outside of someone else playing it!

In sum, this card is worth it. It's not crazy expensive like a lot of higher end cards, but it's just about right if you're someone like me who wants a good looking, casual experience.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Great video card though only a slight issue
Customer Review:
The video card arrived i installed it and right away when I started my PC the fans did not work and I had nVida experience already installed from a 1030 GTX. I ran test on the card only to discover that not only was it not responding anything I was inputting into aorus settings the fans would not respond i contacted amazon tech support they helped a lot thank you guys you are awesome. I finally found a generic program off the net that worked allowing the fans to spin/operate. It also shows the VGA vram and fans RPM and the temp. In a very accurate way which Aorus does not i was pissed off with nvida cause when i tested the vga card it showed there was power going into the fans but and showed the fans had activity but the RPMs were showing 0 across the board. Which gave me the indication these fans were defective which was odd i never came across this issue and even when i ran the card and it reached temps between 84 - 102* the fans did not spin with aorus cause the temp setting was set at 86 and auto and yeah screw aorus If this is how horrible Aorus is becoming then i will not bother with it.

Not sure if anyone came across this issue if they have then just look for another program online

As long as it works with any brand VGA it will work.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
Okay, I'm not saying that this card is the best for gaming because I'm not a gamer. What I am saying is that this card is a great replacement for an older power-hungry video card, especially7 if the older card is causing issues with Windows 10. The older card, using the Nvidia 960 GPU was causing my PC to freeze when the video became complicated. The new card with the 1050 is much smaller and uses a lot less power. In terms of speed, they are pretty much equivalent.

I recommend this card for those who want a decent video card on a budget. The primary use for me is streaming content from the various services (Netflix, Amazon, etc.) It performs flawlessly.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: i got this gpu after my 970 started to mess up on me. this card has been no real improvement. i get frame drops while playing WoW all the time even when on medium and the lowest settings. particles absolutely kill this thing, even when turning them off, i still get random fps drops and hard bottlenecking. save your money and get something else. i will most likely return this and get a different card for my computer. i tried everything from overclocking it, reinstalling drivers and messing with setting but barely got any fps improvements. thsi card does not function well with my i5 6600. dont waste your money here. i only got this card becasue my 970 crapped out on me right before shadowlands released and needed something that would come in on the same day so i could play but it has not been worth it.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
EDIT: So I've upgraded my GPU to a 1080 Ti. This card is still a good card, but in a couple years it will be irrelevant. I still got 60 fps with this card in most games, but you often have to drop settings. For E Sports titles and light gaming I'd recommend this card, but realistically I'd recommend a 1060 or an RX 580 for future proofing. It's not much more expensive and will last you much longer.

Original Review:

So I picked up this card for my HP 6300 Compaq Pro SFF PC. It's got an i5 3570 and 8gb of DDR3 RAM. It had a terrible integrated GFX Card, so I searched for an upgrade. The PC only has a 240w power supply, and is a small form factor case, so size and power was limited in my selection. I found this thing and it claimed it needed no PCIE connection and only used 75w of power. I was skeptical at first but I ordered it.

Well, I can say it works great. This card does a very nice job. I can play PUBG without dropping below 60fps (except while dropping lol) at 1080p with textures/view distance maxed, and of course some other settings dropped. I can also play BF4 at Ultra Preset and never drop below 50fps in multiplayer, and it usually sits around 70-80fps! I plan on trying many more games with this card, but so far it does pretty darn well.

My temperatures would hit 83C at first and it had me nervous, but adjusting fan curve quickly sorted that out. It would never go above 72C after my adjustments, and now with a 150mhz Core/Memory overclock, it never goes above 74C. Bear in mind, this is also a tiny PC (google my PC, you'll see), with very little cooling. I'm sure the card is capable of running cooler, and I plan on improving the cooling of this system in time. Speaking again on the overclock, it does very well. I actually have just stopped overclocking it because it got so boring running tests over and over and over again, but I am positive there is more room to OC it, and I plan on going to it's limits later down the road, but for now performance is great for my $400 build, thanks to this little card. Highly recommend it.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Small package that brings big performance gain! Well beyond what the 1030 will do in about the same sized card.
Customer Review: This is a great little card for space issues (i.e. ATX and ITX Mobos) in a tight little case. This has the biggest bang for the buck of anything that might fit, then you jump up to the standard VGA card form factor which is usually a nightmare with smaller boards and cases. While this won't run most games on Ultra settings, High is plenty for most titles. The one thing about Gigabyte is that if they last more than the first few days you're probably set for a good long time. They do tend to run hotter than other brands regularly, but not so much that they can't be controlled, and this card is no exception. Usually you find a higher base clock with Gigabyte for your dollar than other brands as well, and the fan noise is no more than I would expect. I water cool virtually all of my builds for sale and personal use, but I just installed this one as-is and it's running fine in a 12" by 12" cube from Thermaltake.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
Do you remember those times, back 20 or so years ago, when, if you had a circle on a computer screen, or even a diagonal line, it's more like a bunch of squares than a curve. Then we got rid of that with stuff like Antialiasing.

Well, if you want to put on your nostalgia goggles, then just have this card running in your case for a few weeks, and you'll have the blockiest, edgiest, ugliest text and video that we've seen in the entire decade.

Oh. And the tech support is mostly useless.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

Covered the the only other pcie I had but managed to use a riser cable to relocate the USB 3.0 card. I didn't have to upgrade PSU as the original works great.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Good for upgrading older computers. Does not need special power.
Customer Review: This card will let you run most games at med settings. its limit of only having 2gb ram holds it back from doing ULTRA settings. But its good if you have an older system and just want to do med or light gaming. Its low power requierments means you dont need to fret about having a mega power supply. GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Fine Video card, avoid Aorus Graphics Engine Utility
Customer Review: This video card is fine, installed the drivers and Aorus Graphics Engine Utility. All of my applications worked fine, except I noticed every so often my PC started getting BSOD. I timed it and it was exactly every 23 minutes. That is odd, so I switched back to old VC and it still was happening. After about 2 days of troubleshooting I narrowed it down to the Aorus Graphics Engine Utility. Uninstalled that, leaving the Nvidia drivers and I was all good. If this is happening to anyone else I hope this experience helps.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Great card for a low budget. (This review is for the 2 fan version that requires external power)
Customer Review: Very good graphics card they have here. I upgraded from Gigabyte's GTX 750 ti Windforce edition (the 4 GB model) and paired with my Xeon x5670 and 24 GB of RAM I am able to play everything I throw at this with High to Ultra settings. For example, I am able to max out GTA V (no advanced options on), Wolfenstein: The New Order, Warhammer End Times: Vermintide, Doom (the latest one of course) among quite a few other games at 1080p, 60 FPS or higher. If you want to play newer games at high settings without spending at least several hundred dollars on just the GPU alone, then you should definitely get this graphics card. I went with the larger version with 2 fans that requires external power, because, of course, the beefier cooler, and in most cases the cards that use external power can get better overclocks, and in all cases you can overvoltage them far better as an external power connector can always deliver more power than the pci-e slot. I didn't do too well in the silicon lottery with this one, I wasn't able to get huge overclocks like with my old 750 ti, but even with a mild overclock this thing destroys my old GPU, runs quieter and cooler, and uses less power. This card is also sexy, it looks fantastic as well as having a backplate. I am extremely happy with this graphics card, and I swear by Gigabyte products, as always they are fantastic. One thing to note about the FTW edition, it's quite long and takes up a bit more than 2 slots with the cooler, about twice as long as my old 750 ti Windforce so keep that in mind if you are thinking of buying this, it could conflict with things you already have in your mother board such as sound cards or NICs, and if your case is smaller lengthwise it may not fit. If your case is for instance, micro atx and not a mid tower or larger, go with the smaller version that has a single fan.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: I simply needed to upgrade my XPS8930 from integrated graphics to something better for my use of Autodesk Fusion 360 because of the notification that I got about having "insufficient graphics" even though my pc met the system requirements that the software lists on their website. Now I no longer get the error message my graphics card is virtually silent, and there is no lag when drawing complex drawings for 3d printing(unlike before). I am very happy with this card because it fit my needs perfectly for a good price. Would buy again

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
I purchased this card for my ageing home theater PC. The CPU in it wasn't capable of hardware decoding H.265. Video would constantly jerk as the CPU utilization was at 100% the entire time.

After installation of the card, I can stream a full 1080 stream of H.265 video with very little GPU utilization, and my CPU sits at around 10% usage.

The two best things about this card are the fact that it doesn't require an extra power cable, and that the fan almost never turns on during light HTPC work.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Card is awesome, RBG software great when it works
Customer Review:
The stop fan feature is pretty nice, making the system a little quieter when it isn't necessary. Only problem I'm having is with the RGB software that only opens one time if I restart my PC (Windows 10 Pro 64bit), even if run as admin the second time and beyond. GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
I bought this graphics card because my 1GB AMD Radeon HD 7770 was getting too taxed by zooming around Google 3-D maps. The Radeon fan would kick off into high gear and be really noisy.
So with this Geforce graphics card being 4-times the memory at 4GB, I was thinking it would never have to kick into high gear to cool down with the kind of usage I put it through. Well, it has on a handful of occasions, but thankfully, the fan is quieter. But if it does this with normal video watching and zooming around Google 3-D maps, then I can't give it 5 stars.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
Lenevo 720- with a 240 watt power supply. Had a Nvidia 1030 in, but building a computer for mother meant upgrading mine. At first would not run, then a reboot, then run MSI afterburner overclock feature. I use Novabench to check computer performance, It's fast and simple. I'm getting 97FPS with it overclocked. GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

Edit: 9-8-17
After using this card for a month I can say that I am very pleased with this purchase. I have a dual-monitor setup, main in landscape and secondary in portrait, and have been watching Netflix while playing games. The card doesn't ever heat up too much and runs quietly even under heavy load.
I highly recommend this card to anyone wanting to build a beginner or intermediary gaming pc. It is the best choice when measuring price over performance, especially with the cryptomining operations snatching up the higher end video cards and driving up prices.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: Ordered this for my Dell XPS 8700 and it really helped with the video processing and even bumped up the allowable video resolution for some of the sites i watch movies on. The install was pretty easy. I just had to readjust some cables inside my PC but a simple snap in place and it fit. FYI you will need to have a power source to the video card or it will not work. The Dual HDMI ports allowed me to connect my monitors and extend the display. It also runs ultra quiet i dont even hear the fans moving to the point i went in to check if it was working. Highly Recommend

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
Card is OK, but Aorus software update loaded RGB Fusion which promptly caused the blue screen of death (BSOD) on my windows 10 machine. I neither can use or wanted the software, but an update simply gave it to me none the less.
In short beware if you have Windows 10. Perhaps related I had a major driver issue with another NVIDIA card when I upgraded a desktop to Win 10. BSOD again.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Great item. But packing of shipment? not so much...
Customer Review: Product installed just fine and works great, but was not impressed with how this package was shipped. The box you see in the picture is exactly what it was shipped in, no additional Amazon packaging and the box was not even taped shut. Just a UPS label stuck on the box and sent out the door. As in, this is exactly how it would have been found had I picked it up off a store shelf, not how I'd expect something to be shipped from an Amazon center to my end destination, especially for an item at this price level.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Holy crap this video card runs flawlessly
Customer Review: Tried my luck and purchased the Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E for my HP Desktop Compaq Pro 6200 SFF Core i5-2400 3.10GHz 8GB with original 240-watt power supply. Holy crap this video card runs flawlessly. Breathes life into an old computer and plays all my games on MED or HIGH setting over 60 FPS. I really don't know what else to say but give it a try. GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
When your Brand NEW 1060 goes out and Newegg screwed you by not providing a receipt fornusi g their marketplace thru the website, you resort to the CHEAPEST video card you can find! This baby will play ALL of your dream games so slow, you can see time passing you by. When I go into a FPS game like SW BF 2, you can assure that I enjoy being a shot test dummy by an armada of gamers looking to get some kills in the noob who runs a 1050 into a FPS shooter game with 15-18(if your lucky FPS)FPS game.

Seller, was awesome! Card is great! But a budget card is not a good choice to replace a 1060 when it takes a poop in your gaming rig.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Just what I needed for my fiancees gaming machine
Customer Review: My fiancee had an older 2gb Nvidia graphics card that was really starting to show its age, it could barely handle the load of a single dungeon in World of Warcraft, now with the new card we can run World of Warcraft on almost maximum settings, it's a night and day difference. Installation was super easy, just take out one of the blanks from the back of the computer and install it, no power hookups required since the model I bought is an efficient low power graphics card compared to most higher end cards.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Fits and works for HP 8300 Elite (low profile card))
Customer Review: My old crappy Lenovo wouldn't run solidworks or matalan so I needed an upgrade for school. I put this (the low profile version) in a HP 8300 Elite small form on sale for like 170, bought this used for 170 and dropped 80 on a monitor, so total of 430ish for a new rig that Runs Counter strike, Starcraft 2 and some other older games perfectly, I have yet to buy a new game and test it out but for the money man this things kills as you can throw it into any standard build out

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: Bought this for my daughter's Dell 3650 so she could start playing WoW with my wife and I and man what a difference. The on-board worked ok but this little thing just up'ed her game significantly. I was genuinely surprised to see how well it performed, shes getting a solid 60+ fps at 7/10 in WoW. Also didn't need to upgrade the PSU, so @230w of stock power this thing still runs like a champ. I don't see it ever maxing out the graphic settings of any modern day games but it is definitely a mid-range champ for the price.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: I am not a "gamer". However, according to the reviews, this should have adequate 3D performance should I ever need it. What I like is the 2D performance. My display (Dell P2715Q 4k monitor) never looked better. I didn't think a new video card would make that much difference, but it did. It's faster, crisper, better contrast, better colors, and seems to have better resolution than the Geforce 660 ti card it replaced. Well worth the purchase price for this benefit alone!

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Excellent Entry Level for PC Building
Customer Review: Great for Entry level PC building, not exactly the most power for your money anymore, runs modern and most recent games well at low to medium graphics at 60+ FPS 1080p gaming and higher graphics with lower FPS but can manage. Games that are not so modern run like butter at Max settings with 60+. Not good for VR (Virtual Reality) as expected below the minimum requirements. But other than that it holds up quite okay. Build quality is quite good and durable. I have used this card for a little more than 2 years now and have had no problems, runs as good as the day I got it. It is very quiet and decently cool. Seems pricey at almost $200 but may go down in price. Solid card to get started on.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: Plays AAA titles on medium quality at 1080. Esports can all be played on high settings. The CPU you use with this GPU is very important for multiplayer co-op games, as the hosting pc/player is usually the one tracking all enemies on the battlefield. Use the geforce experience program to tweak the game settings to optimal. This gpu performs excellent for the value. No need to connect a separate PSU 6/8 pin connector means you can install it virtually in any standard form factor desktop. Highly recommend.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: Works good

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
I returned mine, but it was not Gigabyte's fault. Amazon Warehouse shipped this returned item to me, which was apparently returned because it had problems -- black screen occasionally on some web pages. They need to fully test their product before selling a returned item again.

I then bought one locally. It simply works fantastically! Fast and quiet. You can never hear the fan! It's also more energy efficient than the GTX 750 it replaced.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: I got this "lesser" model (it's not the top tire model) because my Dell Optiplex 3050 w/ 8 gig of RAM running WIN 10 was crawling. Adding more RAM could help, but the video would still be processed by the CPU and would still choke. This took the strain off my system and was an easy install. I would recommend getting a vid card before getting more RAM or if your RAM is maxed out.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Great card for folding or gaming
Customer Review:
With EVGA's overclocking app, I could boost the RAM of the OC version, from 3.5Ghz to 4.4GHz, and the CPU from 1.518Mhz to 1800 Mhz without any glitches. I do use it for folding only, so gaming may differ.
With increase in voltage, it can run stable at 2Ghz, 4500Mhz RAM; however it'll run hot, and the fans will be noisier.

Since my rig is on 24/7 I try not to push it. It gets great results in Folding at home, at only 200-250 Mhz boost on CPU, and 900Mhz (to 4,4Ghz) boost on RAM the fans are only running at 50%.
Volume levels increase a lot and it starts to become audible when fans are spinning past 52-54%..

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review: Pretty decent card. It looks good and, as a nice touch, doesn't turn on the fans below 60C which should extend the life of the card quite a bit. I also have a MSI Aero 1050ti in another PC and I can say this in comparison: for some reason the Gigabyte got slightly better framerates in the games that I played. However, I used both to mine ETH on the side when I wasn't using them and the MSI got 14 MH/s to the Gigabyte's 11 MH/s. So I'd pick this one for gaming but the MSI for crypto.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Doubled or trippled framerates over integrated graphics!

Problem solved, although worth mentioning I did also upgrade my Power supply at the same time to support to power connection on this card, I have read this wasn't necessary but I didn't wish to take a chance. Very happy with the upgrade!

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

It's increasing in frequency as well and because Gigabyte's support hours are painfully short, I really never have the opportunity to get support so I'm replacing the card with a good solid midrange AMD card.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

Customer Review: Works great, runs most games much better than auto-detect thinks it can with my processor. Is likely to be better than GPUboss might suggest. CPUboss has some pretty suspect evaluations of AMDs FX series processors as well. Be wary of those websites when making a purchase. Better to get reviews from the owners than from a benchmark. Loving this card and my FX-6300 processor with it (even though it got a 5 out of 10 on CPUboss) It's much faster than my previous processor which got a higher score on CPUboss... but yeah, 1050 Ti is awesome at 768p.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Had a SFF HP Desktop and needed a low-profile card for 1080p gaming.

I am not the richest PC gamer in the universe so the price point was good for me, and the GTX-1050ti offered me the most bang for the buck that was also going to fit into my case and not require a 6 pin plug for power. I have a measly 240w PSU that is proprietary so I had to make power consumption low, and it comes in at 63-75w under load while gaming. I have a Intel i5-4570 CPU and it works well with the GPU, not holding it back significantly. Not the best thing you can buy but if you are building something SFF and/or Low-Profile this card works great.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

Massive upgrade from integrated graphics.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: The GPU is good but I should of just went with the 1070 now that I have it hooked up
Customer Review: The GPU is great. It was sort of a tight fit into my PC build combination but ultimately it popped into place. I shared a picture of this online with my friends on Facebooks(all IT pro's) and my friend John responding back with a GPU that was $30 more and was a 6gb 1060. Anyways, I built this PC so I can upgrade it down the road one of the first things that will get replaced is the GPU. Otherwise, it runs games like Fallout 4 and Battlefield 1 with high settings while I stream. So, it isn't that bad and I got a good deal on it.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review:
Bought this for my rig I built back in 2012. AMD FX6100 cpu which definitely bottlenecks any current mid tier gpu. Bought this to replace an old Gtx 750.

Honestly I should have just used the money towards my new build, since there was little improvement from the old card. It did however, allow me to run an Oculus Rift S, at lowest settings while still being enjoyable on a few titles.

Overall it’s doing the job, but for the $100 in today’s gaming world, you’re better off with a cheaper card or doing a whole new build.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: runs cool, works well on FreeBSD
Customer Review:
A quiet, capable, entry-level 10 series Nvidia. After six months of heavy use, I have to say it works very well. I use mine to drive two busy "productivity" displays with multiple workspaces on a FreeBSD system. The fans rarely kick in (and are not audible over system fans if they do). In the cool of the mid-Atlantic winter, my card has been running at 32-34C in a well-ventilated Corsair case.

I picked this card for:
* large number of outputs (the most of any card pictured on the Nividia site's 1050 page)
* modestly higher clock speeds than the competition, out of the box
* deep fan design (bigger blades can run slower and quieter)
* lower price and power requirements than beefier models
* plenty powerful compared to previous series entry level Nvidia (some of which were barely adequate)

While my use is "productivity", that includes a tremendous number of browser tabs, many of which do leverage hardware acceleration, as well as video playback and light photo editing. This card is beefier than I strictly needed (and would likely be fine for light to medium gaming), but I was also sizing it to handle upgrading from HD to WQHD (which I've done now) and/or driving a third display (which I haven't done yet).

Linux and BSD folks might be interested in the card's dmesg output. This is from FreeBSD 11.1:
nvidia-modeset: Loading NVIDIA Kernel Mode Setting Driver for UNIX platforms 384.90 Tue Sep 19 17:29:32 PDT 2017
nvidia0: <GeForce GTX 1050> on vgapci0
vgapci0: child nvidia0 requested pci_enable_io
hdac0: <NVIDIA (0x0fb9) HDA Controller> mem 0xed080000-0xed083fff irq 17 at device 0.1 on pci1
hdacc0: <NVIDIA (0x0080) HDA CODEC> at cad 0 on hdac0
hdaa0: <NVIDIA (0x0080) Audio Function Group> at nid 1 on hdacc0
pcm0: <NVIDIA (0x0080) (HDMI/DP 8ch)> at nid 4 on hdaa0
pcm1: <NVIDIA (0x0080) (HDMI/DP 8ch)> at nid 5 on hdaa0
pcm2: <NVIDIA (0x0080) (HDMI/DP 8ch)> at nid 6 on hdaa0

This isn't my first Gigabyte video card, and won't be my last. I'm very pleased with it. Recommended.

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)

Customer Review: This is a great example of a 1050ti. It is so quiet, has a 0db fan mode, overclocks well and runs cool. I could recommend it to anyone looking for a 1050ti. The performance is perfectly good for any type of gaming. I have more expensive cards and playing on this one is just as fun. GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: Easy plug and play install. B450M motherboard with Ryzen 3 2200G
Customer Review:
Very easy install. Low profile footprint made the card very easy to place and took up very little room. No external power required as it gets power from motherboard slot.
After hardware installation, drivers needed updated which were easy to find online. The card does come with a disc with drivers, but my PC does not have a CD drive.
Once the card was fully up and running, my PC went from 30ish FPS to a consistent 60FPS. The Ryzen 3 built in graphics work well, but an external card is definitely necessary for higher FPS results.
Overall great product for the price and works well with a budget build PC!

GPU Name: Gigabyte Geforce GTX 1050 Ti OC Low Profile 4GB GDDR5 128 Bit PCI-E Graphic Card (GV-N105TOC-4GL)
Customer Review Title: It does raise your FPS and shader levels, but is it stable?
Customer Review:
Well, overall I'm quite chuffed with the thing. Being that I was simply upgrading to a newer model GeForce, the changeover was pretty easy.

Plopped it in, locked it in, plugged it in, powered in on and off we went! For 3 whole glorious weeks, it was amazing. It died on me while I was reading my news feeds. 3 weeks old. So young. So pretty. So much hope.

I went through the proper Amazon channels and was led to contact the manufacturer directly. If you've not ever done a Gigabyte RMA, allow me to highlight some things you may not be aware of:

1. Call them. The website "works" but it sucks. I registered on it but never got a confirmation email, so to open my RMA I had to call.
2. Once cleared for an RMA you will be sent a gripe sheet and a shipping label (sans postage, that's up to you). You are required to get the RMA item back to Gigabyte.
3. Don't throw away the old box! I'm old, so I have learned that for computer hardware, in particular, it is best to invest some closet space to newly installed hardware upgrade boxes...just in case you need to send it back.

Right now, my major con is that the thing lasted 3 weeks for me. I didn't tamper with it at all when I installed it. The most in-depth bit of "tinkering" I gave it was an update to my video driver. That shouldn't kill a card (and it didn't).

I'm not sure if the video card has a defect or what happened, so I am not inclined to speak poorly of it. Frankly, I'm tempted to offer a 5-star review for how awesome it made playing games (PUGB, Sniper Elite 4 looked sick on here, too). That said, I detracted 1 star because it died on me so quickly.

Provided the RMA goes as I assume it will - smoothly because Gigabyte is a pretty solid company I expect my attitude to stay where it is. Good company, typically rock solid hardware (this is not my first Gigabyte purchase). That said, if this goes sideways, best believe y'all will hear all about it.

GPU Name: Gigabyte GeForce GT 1030 GV-N1030D5-2GL Low Profile 2G Computer Graphics Card
Customer Review Title: All the bang for a little buck!
Customer Review:
Upgrading from an ancient 2012 model GTX 650. For those that don't know, these are ancient and I'm pretty sure my iPhone has better graphics...
Old school AMD quad processor, 4.1ghz
8GB RAM
Win 7

^^ Not high end specs by ANY means. Very ancient in terms of gaming power.
I play everything on low, lower, lowest.

Bought this card, had to tell my BIOS to only talk to one PCI E slot (not sure why since it was the same one from the GTX 650) and install some drivers.

I mainly play WoW these days. Everything literally set to 1 (lowest, with most options disabled)
Rebooted, WoW was immediately on High with some options in particle rendering set to Very High. I fiddled with it and managed to get almost everything to Very High with disabling things I don't care for too much like sunshaft quality, shadow quality, etc., and am still running around idling with a 95-100 FPS. In 25man raids it drops to about 80. Mind you, this is with an ancient cpu and very low ram.

As far as the card itself is concerned, besides being a massive upgrade, it doesn't have any pin connectors or anything, you just slot it home and that's it. Its silent, has a fan/heatsync combo, and stays nice and cool after hours of raiding. It has the option for overclocking, but I just don't need it with WoW. And WoW is also known to be rather demanding when you crank the settings all the way up. I also play Dreadnaught at max settings across the board.

Amazing little card that can breath fresh life into a 6 y.o rig!

GPU Name: Gigabyte GeForce GT 1030 GV-N1030D5-2GL Low Profile 2G Computer Graphics Card
Customer Review Title: Easily one of the best sub-$100 GPU on the market!
Customer Review:
I purchased this to upgrade my older rig- while my "main" PC is in my office, my "old" PC is in my living room- so it does get quite a lot of use. I tend to play fairly easy-to-run games on the PC in question, but even still, the MSI R7 250 2GB DDR3 inside was struggling.

Fable Anniversary could barely pull down 30FPS on medium settings. Wolfenstein The New Order/The Old Blood would be at 25-30FPS on low/medium settings. Even Crusader Kings II, Hearts of Iron III/IV, and Stellaris ran at sub-60FPS on low/medium settings.

I purchased the GT 1030 to remedy these faults, and boy, was I not disappointed. 60+ FPS on Fable Anniversary on max settings. Steady 55-60FPS on Wolfenstein on max (okay, very close to max) settings. Paradox games went from a 20-25FPS to well over 70. I was quite shocked by the latter.

To wrap up my review of its performance- let's talk over clocking. Once (basic) drivers are installed via the included CD, a built in clock control program is also installed. It is easier to use than Afterburner, having safe presets- but does not allow for as much control until specifically placed in "professional" mode. Otherwise, the clock speeds are just fine for a 69 dollar card. On top of that, the VRAM is DDR5- a massive upgrade for those still running DDR3 VRAM.

As to the more physical nature of the card- wow, is it tiny. Less than half the size of my replaced R7 250, probably a quarter of the size of the 1070 in my main computer. Far lighter as well.

Installation was simple, as it only draws power directly from the PCI slot/motherboard. Speaking of power- this thing barely draws any. Can't recall exactly, but I know that it's a minuscule amount. As long as you have a 300-350W power supply, you'll be fine.

Be warned- given the size, this card only produces ONE DVI port and ONE HDMI port. That's it. Just something to think about. I was a bit surprised they didn't put a VGA slot on a card NVIDIA is touting as the answer to every budget gamer's needs- but I digress. I suppose even HDMI-sporting monitors/TVs are cheap nowadays.

Card is whisper silent, although the first time I installed it, it spun hard and fast for a few minutes, and made considerable noise- don't freak out if that happens. She has great thermals, but I do have an overkill cooling setup in this PC, so results there are probably skewed for the average person who isn't obsessed with cooling.

Anyways, a $69, low-profile, Pascal-based, NVIDIA GPU? It's not too good to be true. Give it a shot if you're on a budget, have power or size restrictions,or even if you're just an NVIDIA or GPU enthusiast. It won't replace your 1070, but it will definitely surprise you- especially given its small form factor and low power draw.

Just a quick side note before I stop rambling- don't ask me how but- I'm pretty positive NVIDIA will be releasing a GT 1040 soon, perhaps by the end of the year. For those that aren't in a rush- perhaps wait for that?
