GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: This card is powerful, but really loud by default.
Customer Review:
First I'll disclaim I wanted to initially give this two stars for the noise, then three after I fixed it in my own way, but I'm finally opting for a four star review, mainly because EVGA provides very good service and warranty, and was very responsive to queries online. So consider the card 3.5 stars and an additional half star for the quality of service behind the product.

==============================

I bought this card because Amazon wouldn't allow more than one per household on the MSI GTX 1060 AERO ITX model. This card is technically more powerful than that model, being "superclocked" and all. And I have to admit, it's a great card. However the enclosure and fan leaves something to be desired.

The fan on this card is much too aggressive. Apparently it initially had a max fan speed of 2600RPM but a BIOS update on later revisions bumped it to 3900RPM after some issues with the EVGA 1070 and 1080 models. This card isn't impacted but I guess it was a precautionary measure. But because of this, the card sounds like a jet engine once you get into the mid-50% speeds on the fan, and the stock fan curve is extremely aggressive, ramping up as high as 70%+ speed when the card is around 70c (when it can easily go up to 80c without any throttling or problems). This was a souce of confusion, since video reviews on the card note it's whisper quiet, but that was way back before the vBIOS was changed.

MSI Afterburner or similar software is a must for this card, not for overclocking, but for fan control. A custom fan curve goes a long way, and you can keep this card at around 75c or below at 100% load with a fan speed of about 52%, at least in my case (Corsair Carbide 100R Silent edition with two front intake 120mm fans and one rear exhause 120mm fan). I highly recommend installing MSI Afterburner or EVGA's own Precision X OC immediately after installing this card and setting your own fan curve. Doing so will turn this card from "powerful but I don't want to use it" to just "powerful."

So basically, I tentatively recommend this card. It's good, and a fantastic 1080p gaming card, and pretty decent even at 1440p. But without an aftermarket cooler or a custom fan curve it's really noisy.

=========================

Lastly, a note for Linux users:

Obviously you don't have access to tools like MSI Afterburner. That's cool though, you've got bash. I got some help online and came up with a script that controls this card's GPU (well, any Nvidia card) based on the temperature. You can find it at the link below:

https://pastebin.com/2iANCPEy

The script controls the fan by using an offset value to set the fan speed to an offset of the temperature. If the card is below 56c the fan will stay on at 12% speed which is essentially spinning but inaudible. Once it passes that temperature threshold, it sets the fans speed to the temperature plus the offset. In my case an offset of -22 worked well. That way at 60c the fan will be at 38%, at 70c the fan will be at 48%, and so on. Seems to be perfectly adequate for cooling during gaming, and I'm seeing max temps of around 73-74c under load at 51-52% fan speed with the script. You can modify the offset value however works for you.

To run the script, just make a copy locally and save it, chmod the file with a value of 755 (or just chown it, whatever), and call it with "bash ./filename.sh" If you do "bash ./filename.sh -v" it will do verbose output to the console and display the fan speed and gpu temp at each interval (8 seconds by default). If you're doing this from a remote terminal, you can use ctrl+z and then bg to set it as a background job, or just call it with the & symbol at the end when starting it so it doesn't take over the terminal session.

Be aware, you need to be using the proprietary Nvidia driver for this to work, and you'll need to enable cool bit for fan control via "sudo nvidia-xconfig --cool-bits=4" (or --cool-bits=12 if you'd also like to enable overclocking). Then reboot for the cool-bit value change to take effect. A value of 4 enables manual fan control, 8 for OC in nvidia-settings. 12 enables both. You can also enable voltage control in addition to the rest with a value of 28.

This only works on more recent revisions of the Nvidia driver (I believe versions above 340). I'm on Ubuntu 18.04, and this should work on at minimum 16.04 and up, plus other distros with similar versions and kernels. If you have a really old distro or much older drivers for some reason, you can use the script I originally based mine on, which can be found at the link below:

https://gist.github.com/loathingKernel/995777d2aab6dc82316ea2da62142975

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Two used cards sold to me as new. Both broken.
Customer Review:
Something fishy is going on here. The first card I bought froze up and stuttered and barely worked. After pulling it back out of my system and examining it closely, I see some type of residue on the circuit board that looks like something was spilled on it. I ordered a replacement from Amazon. The replacement had some grease on the bracket and a white sticker with pen hand writing stuck on the circuit board. I didn't like that but this card seemed to work like a charm so I didn't let it bother me. Less than a week using this replacement and it dies on me. Its clear to me that these cards are not new but are being sold as new. That's NOT okay!!!

I just got off the phone with EVGA tech support. Apparently even though it says you are buying these cards from EVGA, you aren't. The people on Amazon selling these cards under the seller name "EVGA" do not work for EVGA. That's extremely misleading and quite frankly I'm not even sure how this is legal. You are damaging EVGA's reputation with a lot of consumers. I would like to be contacted directly by this seller so we can resolve this issue and I can get the product that I actually paid for.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Pretty Fantastic With Just A Few Possible Caveats
Customer Review:
Full disclosure, this is my first graphics card. So this review will mostly be only about the performance of the unit, and no comparisons.

So I stuck this into the Acer TC-780 Desktop along with a nicer PSU. The case was a bit of a tight fit, but it works as intended.

I initially had issues with the card, occasionally it would turn completely off leaving me with a black screen, this may have been a power issue because after unplugging many of my consoles, I have had no issues and it now performs well.

It runs many older games decently at 4k, and I can get some newer games to operate well at that resolution, the card has issues properly handling it. However many games released in the last three years run amazing at 1080p or 1440p and the GTX 1060 handles most games well, even heavily demanding games like The Witcher 3. However I did have many many issues with Assassin's Creed Origins, although that was probably more of an issue with the game itself. When fully utilized in a game, the max temperature I've had has been 75°C with no overclocking. When I was benchmarking with a small overclock, it had reached 80°C but that probably will never happen within a game. About overclocking, this card handles it "okay" but hasn't wowed me. Anything over a +125 mhz overclock causes games to crash and I can't push memory clocks too high as it does cause artifacting among other issues. Overclocking the card does definitely help performance in some games if you favor a higher resolution like I do, but don't want to sacrifice fps too much.

Overall, for my budget, it's a great GPU and it runs laps around the PS4 and Xbox One that I'm used to playing games on. I'm hoping that this review is somewhat informative.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
I've never liked writing shorter tech reviews because certain products are costly. If you overlook something in your research, then you spend more time and money trying to correct it. Also for this review, I use GPU, card, and graphics card interchangeably.

I've wanted to play the more recent console games that have also been coming out for PC, but my NVIDIA GeForce GT 730 GPU for desktop couldn't keep up...not even close. I spent quite a while researching and deliberating between this graphics card or the higher benchmarked 1070 or 1080 version (including the Ti versions) NVIDIA cards. I ultimately went with this 1060 6GB SC from EVGA as I could keep my current power supply unit, and didn't need to replace my 6 pin connector (which would have added to the cost up front and slightly higher electric demand). I'm not considering using ultra-high graphics or manually overclocking this GPU anyways. My logic was it would last me about as long as a console, but was happy to noticed it improved the quality of the display for images/movies over the original, lower-performing 730 GPU. So I might even be able to benefit from it longer still.

Installation: I use Windows 10--not sure if this is important, but maybe helpful for you. I've never installed a graphics card in my life, so after reading/watching how it was done online, I found it superbly easy once inside the machine. Ridiculously easy even. I did have some trouble with the software installing from CD (the EVGA website has it anyways all nicely updated so it saves time from needing a second update), but the included benchmarking software (including one for VR) went on a-okay. Was way easier then expected.

Impressions during play/viewing: Remember how I said my old, basic 730 GPU couldn't keep up with newer games? This1060 SC graphics card fixes a 1-5 second processing delay the old GPU gave me (and I was really sacrificing graphics quality on that old card). Now, I am running with higher quality graphic settings in-game and my gameplay is no longer lagging from intense graphics. No problems yet during gameplay with STEAM's and NVIDIA software's recommended settings, and the only periods in gameplay it seemed to have trouble with was graphically intense cutscenes. [Not sure if that is really this card's fault as the game is a hybrid between local files and network connection.] The fan on this card is probably the noisiest one on my whole desktop (become aware when the fan kicks up, but it's nowhere near jump-scaring me), but I hear that noise level is common across all these NVIDIA 10-series GPUs. I'm glad EVGA designs their fans to be slightly quieter because of this. Other games that worked with my old GPU (think RPGs, World of Warships, etc) actually look sharper for better or worse (it highlights quality of detail the designers put into it the game, but also highlights some of the graphical imperfections--still not complaining though since stuff loads great at on good quality settings). Outside of gameplay, my background images that cycle for my PC are significantly enhanced both in textures and colors. To give you an idea, one of my backgrounds is a landscape that has a brushstroke effect that is now showing up significantly clearer--something I could notice on my old 730 GPU, but nothing with this detail.

Other impressions: It's not a full-length desktop card, but the card has significant bulk and heft to it. Was actually surprised by the size and how sturdy it looked and felt since I mostly know friends that use gaming laptops. As far as detail goes, others are commenting on how much sharper things look from my PC now, and I haven't even changed my monitor! I'm sure this already is obvious, but if you are gaming expect heat generation. Keep that in mind in case its hot outside or now that winter is coming.

Will update should anything change or find something else out that's cool about it.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: 2164 Mhz GPU Core Clock / 4498 Mhz Memory Clock on Liquid Metal with Additional Air Cooling!
Customer Review:
Amazing product . I did use the following products also to overclock with this:

Thermal Grizzly Liquid Metal ( Warning this probably does void your warranty - I used this to replace the stock GPU Paste )
Thermal Grizzly Conductonaut Thermal Grease Paste - 1.0 Gram

Titan Adjustable PCIE FAN ( Placed under the EVGA GTX 1060 for increased airflow )
Titan Adjustable Dual Fan PCI Slot VGA Cooler (TTC-SC07TZ)

Sally Hansen Clear Nail Polish ( For covering the capacitors and power connectors around the GPU because Nail Polish is Non-Conductive )
Sally Hansen Color Therapy Nail Polish, Top Coat 0.5 Ounce Long-Lasting Nail Polish with Gel Shine and Nourishing Care

DISCLAIMER: I don't recommend you try the modifications I have in my review unless you know what you are doing, do so at your own risk as this most likely will void your warranty. But if $350 doesn't matter to you and you are an expert, then read on.

I first unscrewed the cooler from the Graphics Card on the back plate with 4 phillips screws and disconnected the side fan connector, this exposed the copper heat sink and the GPU. I used Alcohol Wipes to gently remove all of the stock GPU Paste and waited a few minutes to dry, then I used the Sally Hansen Color Theraphy Nail Polish, which by the way is NON CONDUCTIVE and is safe to use, by applying it around the GPU Die on the capacitors and power connectors creating a protective cover. I waited 10 minutes for it to dry and then applied 3 more layers, this was done to prevent a power short circuit in case liquid metal got on the capacitors around the GPU Die. Just to be clear the Nail Polish was placed around the GPU and note directly on it. Once the Capacitors were completely covered in Nail Polish, I placed a pea sides amount of liquid metal on the GPU Die and used the QTIP to spread it nice and evenly on the GPU Die like butter.

Turning on my computer the Idle Temperature went from 42 Degrees Stock Paste to 36 Degrees Ambient Temperature with the Liquid Metal.

Starting off with testing, I did download the latest drivers from EVGA Website and as of this review it is display driver 398.11 with BIOS 86.06.68.00.62 as of 06/06/2018.

Stock the card does come with a stock clock speed of 1607 MHz / Real Boost Clock: 1835 MHz. However, I was able to get that up to 2164 Mhz on the GPU Clock and 4498 Mhz on the Memory clock.

Using the following settings with my modifications, I downloaded EVGA Precision OC from EVGA's website and also EVGA Scanner X

For EVGA Precision OC I used the following settings:

Turn on KBOOST ( Forces GPU to operate at full boost clock 100% of the time)

120% Power Target (This is your TDP - Thermal Design Power) - Gives your Graphics Card 20% more power for higher overclocks
Break the link for both Power Target and Temperature ( You want this so that you get more power regardless of temperature)
Set Priority to Power Target

For Voltage I set it to 70%
For Fan Speed, I set it to 70% ( It's loud but I can use a Gaming Headset )

GPU Clock Speed Offset set to +160 Mhz
Memory Clock Offset set to +496 Mhz

Also Motherboard Southbridge Voltage was increased to 1.25 Volts, VDDR Voltage increased to 1.25 Volts, VDDR PCIE Voltage increased to 1.25 Volts. This was done to increase power delivery to the Graphics Card from the PCIE Slot on the motherboard due to the high 120% TDP.

Running a stress test for at 4K Resolution at 3840 x 2160 Pixels with 8X MSAA produced a steady frame rate of 43 Frames Per Second at 65 Degrees Celcius, up from 10 Frames Per Second at stock and this test ran for 10 minutes rendering over 25,000 Frames without crashing.

This pretty much turned my GTX 1060 into a GTX 1070 for a much lower price as the 1070's sell for about $500 and made gaming at 4K on the 1060 to be actually playable.

Gamers probably won't need to run 8X MSAA and can do just fine with 2X MSAA when Gaming at 4K with my modifications since you can't really notice jagged edges at 2X Anti Aliasing and 4K and overclocked the frames never ran below 30 Frames per second.

Final Conclusion:

The EVGA GTX 1060 6GB overclocks like a champ and with liquid metal, great cooling fans from your case and a PCIE Fan Cooler, you can easily turn your overclocked 1060 into a stock 1070 when running at 4K Resolution that is 24/7 Stable. Your results may vary with the Silicon Lottery, but I highly recommend this product if you are buying it with overclocking in mind, it does great. Pushing it past 2,200 Mhz however did not happen for me and most I was able to do was 2164 Mhz, it is probably possible to go to 2,200 Mhz by doing shunting mods, but that is probably a 2-4% increase in performance from 2164 Mhz and honestly not worth it IMO.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Great value upgrade to a Dell XPS 8900
Customer Review:
I wanted to upgrade the graphics card in my four year old Dell XPS8900, as the installed GTX 745 was lagging in some high resolution flight simulators. With a target price of $200ish, I spent a couple of days researching the options. I have been a satisfied NVidia user for years, and focused on their line of processors.
The final options were the GTX 1050Ti 4GB VRAM and the GTX 1060 3 or 6 GB VRAM, all in the SuperClocked (SC) version (with SC the card automatically overclocks itself in demand within maximum temperature/frequency limits, a great feature for an additional ~$10).
I chose the GTX 1060/3GB as the best "bang for the buck", as it was reviewed and benchmarked significantly faster than the 1050 for a slight cost premium, and the slight additional performance of the 6GB version over the 3GB wasn't justified by the additional cost, and my requirement for less than maximum gaming performance at 1080P, 150 FPS and Ultra resolution settings...
One thing I learned was that the GTX 1050 cards install without an additional power connection, while the GTX 1060 and up require a 6 pin power connector from the power supply. In many modern computers, this connector is supplied, but in older PCs, it may be missing, but that can be "worked around" with a MOLEX/6 pin adapter.
When it came to which manufacturer to use, the EVGA rated the best value and performance, so it was the vendor of choice.
Installation was painless, but many web reviews recommended upgrading the BIOS to the latest version to ensure the XPS 8900 would boot properly. *
PROS
Value
Performance
Easy installation
nVidia software/website
CONS
6 pin power connector required, may not be available in some systems, adapter required

* An ancillary problem with the BIOS upgrade was that after updating the BIOS, I logged in to Windows 10 with my personal ID, but the PC booted into the generic ADMINISTRATOR account. The result was that it booted into the bare bones blue generic Windows desktop, with all but a dozen of my desktop shortcuts missing... After some colorful language, I accidentally discovered that Windows had somehow booted into Win 10 from my log in to the ADMIN account...

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Surprisingly cool for a single-fan ACX!
Customer Review:
Don't let a single fan fool you!

I bought this card worried about just that, and let me tell you, I'm eagerly surprised. I haven't taken the shroud off of the card to put new paste on it either; a proper fan profile with Afterburner or PrecisionX and you'll be just fine. I haven't seen my card go over 63C, and it's rated to tolerate much higher. Plus, in Afterburner it autoclocks it to 2000MHz, though it runs anywhere from 400 to 1600 with idling and light gaming.

The most 'intensive' games I play revolves around Doom (2016), Rust, GTA V, Metro Last Light and The Forest. I don't know the exact average, but I'll put what I remember from said games in regards to frames per second.

Also keep in mind the processor can also affect performance, as well as the RAM when it comes to Ryzen. I'm using a Ryzen 5 1600 and 8GB Corsair Vengeance LPX RAM.

Doom: Ran everything on Ultra/highest possible settings on everything, 1920 x 1080. Dipped slightly below 60FPS once in a blue moon, but never under 57FPS. Very smooth.

Rust: Honestly Rust still has some sketchy optimization, but it never drops under 70FPS (1920 x 1080, minimal settings w/FXAA on and a render distance of 2,500) for me. I've also played w/everything maxed out on some empty/almost empty servers and averaged right around 85FPS. Of course, that's an empty world; a populated world got me right around 45FPS (200 out of 300 slots being played) which is playable, but definitely not recommended for a game like Rust.

Metro Last Light: Never went below 60 FPS. Everything on Ultra, 1920 x 1080. If you never want to go below 60FPS with the same setup as I have, just turn everything on High instead of Ultra. The look is negligibly different.

The Forest: Is optimized horribly, so your experience may vary. Usually 50+ FPS on mid-high settings, but going Ultra on a game that's still in alpha is honestly a stupid decision anyhow.

GTA V: Most settings on High, population density smack dab in the middle. Game looks pretty, never drops below 75FPS. 1920 x 1080.

I love this little card. It's cute as a button but performs like an Olympian.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
Upgraded from an EVGA GTX 660 Superclocked to the GTX 1060 3GB and what a difference! Ok, yes, I know. The 660 is several generations older and so of course the 1060 would be faster, duh. However, what I am so impressed with is how well this card performs when gaming at 1080p @ 60Hz, meaning you don't need more than 60fps. I'm able to game at high or ultra settings on games like Fallout 4, Batman Arkham Knight, Crysis 3, Titanfall, Witcher 3 and others at or above 60fps average. There are dips in frames, but this is due more to my CPU than the card. I'm currently using an AMD FX 4350 OC'd to 4.6Ghz, and it just can't keep this GPU fed with enough data. Card sits at times at about 35%-45% utilization while my CPU is pegged at or near 99%, so CPU bottleneck.

I would recommend this card to anyone looking to game at 1080p @ 60fps on triple-A titles. (If you play WOW, Rocket League, or esport games then go with the 1050ti.) The single fan does plenty to keep the card cooled, and with good airflow in your case it can actually overclock itself even higher. The 3GB VRam does impose a limit on 1440p gaming (lower fps), and 4k is a no-go on most titles, but for those of us on 1080p monitors this card is a beast.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Good choice to play Forza Horizon 3 in 1080p in high setting on Dell XPS 8910 with stock 460 W power supply
Customer Review:
I purchased this card to replace the GeGorce GTX 750Ti that came with a Intel i7-based Dell XPS 8910 (aka Dell Tower) as the 750Ti was too slow to play Forza Horizon 3 in high setting.
With the latest Nvidia drivers already installed for the 750 Ti and latest Dell BIOS already flashed, installation was very easy: turn PC off, open side panel, slide power supply out of the way, take 750 Ti out, put 1060 in, slide power supply back in, connect power supply 6-pin connector to 1060, make sure no cable touches the fan, close side panel, turn PC on, wait a few minutes for Windows to recognize that card has changed, then good to go.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Great, inexpensive graphics card for 1080p gaming
Customer Review: For most people that just need a reliable, lower-end graphics card, capable of playing most games from the past few years, at medium to high settings, this card can work for you. By now, it's a few years old, and thus outdated compared to the newer cards that have taken its place, and the price is probably too high compared to the new gen replacements, but this card, especially used will still managed 60FPS on most games at reasonable settings, and many games at 60FPS or MORE at high or better settings. You'll be hard pressed to NOT get at least 30FPS at Ultra settings at 1080p.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Great value, good frame rates at ultra quality
Customer Review:
This review is of the EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB GDDR5 Superclocked card, p/n 03g-p4-6162-kr

I got this quite a few months back, and at the time graphics cards were still at a premium due to crypto currency mining. I researched performance of the different models, and realized the 1060s were far better than the 1050s, and only slightly slower than the 1070s, with the 1080s being way out of my price range. And despite some really adamant bloggers complaining about the diminished architecture of the 3GB version, in real world performance testing, the 3gb and 6gb cards were functioning nearly identical. So when this particular card went on sale, I jumped on it. I've had no problems with EVGA products in the past, and they tend to out preform the competition with their OC models.

One nice thing is size. It was easier to both install and remove, because there isn't more card blocking access to the PCIe x16 riser lock. When everything else is hooked up, that can be difficult to get to.

Another great thing is that it needs just a single fan. That means it's quiet. And unless the graphics are getting really intense, that fan doesn't even need to run much of the time.

This card comes with a good combination of ports. Ok, so to hook up all there of my dvi monitors, I had to buy two new cables, but it does support several monitors, which is great when working from home.

Note: I honestly haven't looked into whether or not this card supports 3d output to multiple monitors, since most games do a terrible job of supporting it.

I'm not an FPS fan, but I did want better performance and quality from the games I do play (Battletech, Fallout, a bunch of steam games, etc.). This card was an upgrade to my old PC, replacing a GTX570, and it significantly improved my frame rates, with higher quality settings.

I've since built a new PC based off the i5-9600k, and this is still a perfect video card for what I'm playing right now. I'm playing all my games on the highest quality settings, and maxing the refresh rate of my aging 60Hz monitors. I expect I'll upgrade in a year or two, and probably buy a new gaming monitor at that time, too. For now, this still meet my needs, and I'm very happy with it.

I haven't seen any graphical glitches, or had any crashes. The Nvidia driver installs are flawless, as always.

There is a utility from EVGA, Precision XOC, that looks great for those that really want to control their overclock settings, but I haven't had need to mess with it at all.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

It runs fine but my only issue with it is that it runs very hot playing any game other than less demanding games like csgo. Turns out the heatsink on this card has no heatpipes and it looks very similar the heatsink you'd see on a stock ryzen cpu cooler. Therefore whenever she plays any AAA titles or other demanding games it immediately hits 82c (the stock temp target which i haven't changed) and the fan whirs up very loudly. The SC variant of this card has a better heatsink with copper heatpipes that presumably should cool the card much better. I've considered getting an aftermarket cooler for this card but I haven't gotten around to it yet. Perhaps if I ever install it I'll give an update here.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

I loved the smaller form factor, as my next build was going to be an itx or micro atx, but i didnt get the chance to do that. I got a newer system with an i5 6500 and it ran the games without the stutter, and everything ran on the highest settings. GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: it makes less noise than my 120mm Enermax super quiet case fan
Customer Review:
So I really wanted a GTX 1080 or 1070ti, but I couldn't justify the cost. Also, although the rest of my rig is high quality and plenty fast, it's a couple of years old now. When I plugged in this new card I was half expecting it to be loud and underwhelming and hoped that I had not oversold this 1060 to myself.

Well, holy pixels, Batman! Was I ever wrong. This card is blisteringly fast AND quiet. In fact, it makes less noise than my 120mm Enermax super quiet case fan. I think I can eve hear my old 7200 rpm D drive spinning in there!

Fired up Warframe and it runs highest settings (all the AA, filtering, bloom, you name it) in 1920x1080 (DVI,60hz) without breaking a sweat. I even did a Void run with a full 4 player squad, place was lit up like Christmas and the 4th of July in Times Square on New Years and nary a frame rate drop was noticed.

Now if I could just get my wife's Sims4 to run ;-P

If you are on the fence - buy it.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: This card doesn't look like much, but it's an absolute beast. It runs basically every game I throw at it, at highest settings, and never has any issues. I play Rocket League, CS:GO, Golf with Friends, Roblox, Kerbal Space Program, Diablo 3, Garry's Mod, H1Z1: KOTK, PUBG, and more on highest or near-highest settings. I consistently get 100+ FPS on most games, and up to 200 FPS on light-weight games like CS:GO and Rocket League. With only one fan, this card is practically silent, and it's very small as well. Nobody will think of this card as a powerhouse by the way it looks, but it out-performs most other 1060 series cards that I've seen.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Solid upgrade from GTX 750 Ti FTW
Customer Review:
I bought this because I wanted to be able to utilize my new Asus monitor that supported 144hz. With the previous GPU (GTX 750 Ti FTW) I could run Final Fantasy 14 on Medium/high settings ranging from 40-50 FPS at 60hz.

Upgraded to this GTX 1060 and enabled 144hz, put the game on Maximum settings, and I run at a constant 70 -100 FPS. Man, what a difference. 144hz is amazing to game with.

However, the card makes a lot of noise when I play FF14 and Rocket League. I'm slightly concerned with how loud the fan is, and I'm starting to think I should have gone with the dual fan version of the 1060. It could be something else causing this, but I haven't over-clocked anything.

Edit: I downloaded "Precision X" which is a control center for NVIDIA cards. I adjusted the fan settings, and it no longer sounds like it's overheating.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: great card for 1080p or mild 1440p gaming if you can find it in $250 price range
Customer Review:
I got this last fall from Amazon Warehouse Deals in Like New (box was a dinger) and this thing has ran like a champ since then I use it mainly for gaming and playing Fortnite, PUBG, Rainbow six and other various games. I recently upgraded to a 1440p 144hz Gsync monitor and this card still performs really well, well above 60fps if you are willing to play on Medium to high settings.

If you want to break 144fps on 1440p with this card, be willing to turn settings down to low or hope the game is well optimized like Fortnite or Overwatch. This card idles for me around 37c and peaks temps during gameplay have been no hotter than 66c or so. If you can find one around MSRP price, its a no brainer for 1080p gaming or low to medium 1440p gaming. Fan is rather loud since its a single fan card but if you game with a headset on, you wont notice it. Fan does not turn on until card breaks 44c for me which means its silent when I am not gaming.

I am running this card with a i7 3770k OC'd to 4.2ghz and 16gb of ddr3 1600mhz ram.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
The good news is if you get a card that isn't defective like many of the other reviews show, it runs initially pretty well. I was running everything on max with ease. The problem however is it's extremely hot. Any reports mentioning that heat is not an exaggeration, and it has a single fan. Within three days mine finally gave up with a hard boot and now every type of video hard artifacts and games run at 25 frames or less before crashing.

I've had defective cards in the past so I suppose it isn't unique to this one, but now that I have the problem and I'm looking over the other reviews I can very must attest that these people aren't exaggerating and that these are reoccurring problems that should be addressed. I would say take it seriously and perhaps invest in a card that, at minimum, at least runs cooler. No amount of Customer Support copypasta is going to change that.

I was honestly considering dropping a one star because I'm kind of irritated that I can't exchange for another card to just see if it was a manufacturing error, but sending it, then waiting another week for a refund, then purchasing it would make me out of a GPU for two weeks. No thank you. Rating that criticism on the card itself seemed too harsh.

tl;dr: When you buy this card, you're gambling on how long it'll last. If you get a good one, congratulations, enjoy a pretty solid card at a very good price. Don't be surprised if it doesn't last.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Rock solid performance without breaking the bank
Customer Review: This isn't a bad card at all if you're looking for something that can comfortably run games at high/ultra settings @ 1080p. Everything I've tested so far has run at no less than 60fps even when there's a lot going on onscreen, and that's usually with maxed out settings. The 3GB of vram is enough to get the job done in most cases and you're only going to run into lower fps than that if you're trying to go for the extra high Anti Aliasing or uncompressed HD textures that some games offer. But at that point its only because you'd need more than 3GB to support that. In which case the 6GB model is what you'd want anyway to begin with. In either case this card isn't super expensive so if you're looking to work with a budget I'd save a few bucks more to get this over the 1050ti despite it having a little more vram and being slightly cheaper. The difference in performance is significant enough to be worth an extra 70 dollars.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
This GPU is very nice! I came from a GT 220, so upgrading to this was wow! It blows gaming out of the water, and runs very cool. MY GPU fan hardly ever spins, that's right, the GPU fan only spins when the GPU reaches 60 Celsius. My GPU runs almost 95% of the time below 55 Celsius even during gaming. The GPU plugged right into the MOBO, and features many input options for monitors. I use the HDMI input for my GPU and the quality of gaming is amazing.

EVGA even has a great 3 year warranty on GPUs, so you can't go wrong with the company either.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: This compact version is every bit as good as its larger cousins. The one fan seems to work quite well, and though far from noisy is a bit louder than I expected. Set to its power-saving profile the fan gets up to 50% and is very quiet--keeping the card at 82 Celsius or lower (the card will throttle back at 83 degrees). Since the safe temperature for the card is well into the 90s, I'm comfortable running it with the lower fan curve and hopefully extending the life of the fan a bit. As I'm still running games in 1080, this card is phenomenal; I can run almost everything at ultra settings.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: When I ordered this GPU I felt I was settling for the best I could afford (and I was, no joke). But I have been pleasantly surprised with this card. I'm able to run most current AAA games like Battlefield V, Civilization VI, CoD Black Ops 4, etc on Ultra settings at 1440p and 90+ fps. For anyone building a mid-range budget PC, this is the card for you. Don't waste your money on anything less, and don't feel like you have to shell out the big bucks for a better card, this one is quite adequate right now. Even after the 2000 series, it's still the card to have if you can't go 1080Ti or better.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Remember plug your computer screen directly to the video card rather than the back of the mother board!
Customer Review: I was so excited to plug this in to upgrade my current computer that is a generic store bought computer. I plugged this in and set everything up, only to not have the computer boot correctly or recognize the device. I called EVGA for help to be told that the device probably won't work with my computer that has the VGA internalized with the mother board. It took my 15 year old son to realize that we never moved the plug for the video screen from the original plug in the back of the mother board to the new plug of the new video card. DUH! I can't believe I neglected to do that. We also disabled the original video card (via instructions found on the web). And now it works perfectly. Granted it's too fast for the other components my slightly outdated computer has, but once we set the graphics speed lower, at least we can run much higher level games now that used to lag badly.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

Highly Recommend.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Minus the price I paid, I'm pretty darn happy I ordered this.
Customer Review:
Hate the price I paid for it. After tax it was over $100 the MSRP of $250. you can buy used cards around that price, but I'm going to sell this to a friend once new cards come out and it makes it better for him knowing it was recently new and taken care of.

Now to the actual performance! If you've got 1080p, you're pretty set. I came from a 660 2GB that was running into walls with large worlds. My VRAM would be eaten up quite fast! In Fary Cry 5 I had to set everything to low and play at 1600 x 900.
Now I have it up to ULTRA and 1080p with over 3.8 GB Vram to spare! Wildlands uses the most taking up a little over 4GB with everything cranked up. But most importantly, I can FINALLY play Just Cause 3! It ran pretty poorly on my 660, but after this it's buttery smooth and I'm blowing up all sorts of things!
It fit in my case pretty easily. It also doesn't get hot for me so far, so it has not been loud at all.
It's like when I bought my 9800 GTX+, then my 460, then my 660, and now my 1060.... The feeling of cranking up details and settings after dealing with lower settings is a fantastic feeling.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
Well, this is my first ever desktop graphics card that I have purchased, so view my words from that perspective.

It was pretty much plug and play. Packaging was decent with bubble wrap protecting the card, and after removing all the plastics protecting the pretty glossy detailing on the card, installation was pretty much a breeze.

Put the card through it's paces using EVGA's Precision XOC. Managed to retain steady temperatures of around 60 - 65C with a custom aggressive fan curve, and this is maxing out the voltage and temperature limits (priority temps). This card did come overclocked out of the factory, but I managed to push it beyond stock clock by 150 mhz for both memory and clock speeds.

Witcher 3 on ultra with reduced settings on hair works and shadows was easily handled with frame rates well above 60, overwatch could be maxed out at epic while maintaining 90 - 10 FPS, and funnily enough, Borderlands the Pre Sequel was the most demanding of the lot thanks to NVIDIA PhysX, which I heard was very demanding.

For the decent price (got it at 176 USD), I cannot complain. It's a very decent card which can maintain steady temperatures provided you do not mind the fan noise. Honestly, when the game volume's up you cannot notice the fans. I kept them running at about 80-90% to maintain such temperatures.

Will definitely purchase my next upgrade from EVGA in the future.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: I've read some complaints about noise... have no idea what they're talking about.
Customer Review: I got mine about a week ago. I'm only a part-time gamer, but graphic rendering and image quality are still very important to me. My computer is very quiet, so I'd think if my graphics card was making any noise at all, I'd hear it. Zilch. No noise at all. By the way, none of the reviews mentioned this... this card is rated for Windows 10, so if your Windows 10 (upgraded from Windows 8) machine is crashing after the most recent Windows 10 update, it's most likely your video card... and updating the driver probably won't fix it. Save yourself the headache and buy this card.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
GTX1060 (single fan) purchased to go into an old Gateway (Acer) PC. to replace a burned out Nvidia GTX560TI

Space limitations of case made this card the only practical option . As such it worked perfectly.

My system has No cpu or gps overclock.

Installation was complicated (sarcasm)

Disconnect power.

Unplug old cps, undo screws and clamp at slot , then remove gps

Run your hands over metal of your pc case to kill static.

Remove new gps from box then remove from plastic bag

Remove rubber electrical from electrical connector

Insert gps in slot , apply slot clamp apply screws, apply connector.

Check over everything

Turn on power

Win 10 burped my pc off and on twice doing driver install.

After it was complete and all seemed okay .I then installed Nvidia GEForce and their drivers.

No noise, no fan whine this is a great little card.

I set a 3840 x 2160 desktop - super look - this card rocks.

(Games played - EVE ,Skyrim, NMS, OpenTTD, Civ5, Borderlands2, World of Tanks etc_ most at top level graphics settings for my Acer monitor.)

PS the new GTX2060 is now out and 30% faster if you want to spend the extra money.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: The card will mess up by itself
Customer Review:
I bought this card around August of 2018, so around 11 months ago. The card is good in what you would typically expect the 1060 to be, but the card started to malfunction around February of this year. It will sometimes give visual bugs and sometimes will freeze the graphics of games. I decided enough was enough and used NovaBench to test the graphics card health.. it was 200 points off of what you would typically expect the life of the graphics card to be, and it has only roughly been used for about a year.

If you want to buy this card after reading this, then I caution you to buy the graphics card in-store at a Best Buy or Frys or buy a different brand. I will be upgrading the card soon, but I will admit I am really disappointed on the outcome of this graphics card. I’ve been a big fan of EVGA for my first computer build as it is inexpensive and worked just at great as the others, but this issue really will turn me away from buying future graphics cards from EVGA and other products from them. I guess the saying is true, “dont cheap out on computer parts.” You live and you learn.

Thank you for reading my review and I hope my experience has given you the knowledge to make an informed decision.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: I can't say enough good things about this card. I had an application that could only fit a short card, and only had 6-pin power to work with (and was replacing a GT 640). I was wrong, this thing is every bit as powerful, at least for number crunching. I was also sceptical of how the single-fan card would stay cool. My concerns were not founded. GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Returned defective parts resold through Amazon Warehouse Deals
Customer Review:
The GTX 1060 3GB card I bought will generate a screen through its HDMI port, however the card is not fully functional.

Malfunction of this card is not noticeable until the card is used in a way that requires all its CUDA cores. For example, I use the card for number crunching doing grid computing. This card is doing half as much work as any one of the other four (4) GTX 1060 3MB cards I own. I moved the card to a second identical known good computer with the same bad results. Therefore, the problem is with the card, not the host computer.

Secondly, a previous Amazon customer returned this defective card to Amazon before it was resold to me. How do I know? Because my package mistakenly contained a “riser adapter” that only crypto miners use. No Riser adapter comes with the stock GTX 1060. Therefore, the crypto miner discovered the same problem I have discovered. I believe the first owner returned the card before Amazon Warehouse wrongly declared the card is good, then resold it to me. I cannot recommend Amazon Warehouse Deals.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Good pricing and great peformance so far!
Customer Review:
What made me decided to buy one:
I've been on an Nvidia GTX 760 SC that was manufactured by EVGA for around 2 and a half years and it was beginning to show it's age somewhat. There would be stutters and sometimes crazy framerates(Not unplayable however) on certain games (Overwatch and Witcher 3:Wild Hunt being big ones that come to mind) and sure I could downgrade some of my settings to achieve a more stable framerate but I wanted to really push cards to their limits and enjoy 1080P PC gaming at it's best. I assumed it was time to upgrade because I wanted to play on maximum settings on games and prepare my computer for upcoming titles such as Destiny 2 and Assassins Creed: Origins for example. Six months later after owning this card, I can definately say it's one of the smarter purchases I've made.

How well does it run games and is it loud or does it get hot?:
For 1080P gaming this will suit your needs as of now(9/9/17) and most likely for the next few years. The specs on this card compare to the Nvidia GTX 980 but it's ever so slightly worse in some situations or better in others. It all boils down to how well optimized the game actually is. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt saw a performance increase of almost double at 1080P with ultra settings, going from about an average of 25FPS with the 760 SC to about 60 FPS in a lot of places except for densely populated places with the 1060 SSC!
The card also runs very quietly and very efficiently as well. The fans are actually one of the more impressive parts believe it or not. The way they're designed to last almost four times as long(We'll see about that!) and with proper ventilation of heat, could not turn at all(It's a good thing actually, that's how they're supposed to work) to keep power costs lower. When actually gaming or doing strenuous tasks the fans will turn obviously. Heat isn't an issue if even if you have the most basic form of ventilation(like I do and which is why I bought the double fan) The card fits into a mid tower case which is also nice.

Why this card would be good for you:
It may seem like I'm worshipping this graphics card, but I won't deny it has a specific role and if used for other things that isn't 1080P you're either paying too much or didn't get a beefy enough GPU. For example, if you plan to go onto 1440P or 4k gaming, don't bother with this and stead go to the GTX 1070 or GTX 1080. The GTX 1060 won't able to match the performance of those cards with that type of resolution, it's built for great 1080P gaming. Also if you're comming from the 900 series, more specifically the GTX 970 or 980 and especially the 980 TI, you wouldn't get much of a performace gain and in the case of the 980 TI, will be a downgrade in terms of performance. If you're comming from the 700 Series, before that even or switching from AMD to Nvidia and want some of the best cost performance 1080P graphics cards, this is rightfully for you!

TL:DR: Upgraded from a 760 SC from EVGA to this, great performance, quiet, no bad heating, recommended for 1080P gaming or for those looking to upgrade from an older card that isn't from the 900 series as it offers similar performance to them.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
Great product. Running in a custom rig, no overclocking, gets the job done.

As with most cards, knowing what is running is important. So playing PUBG on a step above 1080p (not 4k, I think it is 1980x1200), 12 GB DDR3, solid state hard drive and i7 960 (its been a while but it is still ticking), I get about 50-60 fps pretty consistently on the highest settings.

Hookup was easy, total replacement time was about 5 minutes, updated drivers and settings, and then was rolling. Worth the money if jumping from 2GB 760 as I did.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Amazing Performance... WOW! Just Get One for Yourself
Customer Review:
I am not given to writing reviews for the most part... but this graphics card is amazing. Granted I am boosting a pre-built Acer TC-780 but Daaaaannnngggg unbelievable upgrade on the graphics side of the house.

Heaven Benchmark 4.0 went from 11 FPS on integrated Intel HD 630 to an average of 121 FPS on Ultra settings... Turning on max Tessalation and Anti-aliasing kept an average of 67 FPS.

phenomenal UserBenchMark Gaming score went from 17% (Surfboard) to 77% (Battleship)

Starcraft II went from 1 FPS with Over 600 hundred units attacking at Medium graphics to 69 FPS at Extreme graphics settings.

Beautiful upgrade that is an incredible value and the single fan allows temps that are amazingly cool on a 120w card and yes it runs perfectly with the OEM 300w power supply.

Nothing to say... get one and be happy ;)

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Not seeing a way to leave feedback
Customer Review:
It works, installs easily - good mid-level card.
I don't see a way to leave feedback other than a review.
Every other package has been at the front door, UPS dropped this one on the ground at the community mailbox of my apartments. That is a very public high traffic place right by the complex entry I'm glad I stumbled across it there when I went to check for mail, I'm glad the package was still there. I will be resistant to purchase pricey items because of it.
The package was still sealed, The box inside the package was open, the card had been removed and put back in the ESD bag. I don't know if it's new or used, but the card works and that is also important.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
For the price, you can't really beat a card like this. It's one of the best cards that I've bought as I'm a mid range gamer so I can't justify going out and dropping 500 or 600 dollars on a video card. So if you want great gaming performance at a great price then go with this card... Installation was easy as well as tweaking it. The 0% fan mode is nice when you're not doing any intensive work or gaming with the card..

One thing I would consider adding is functionality for SLI.. I get these types of cards are meant for SFF but even with some smaller cases you would be able to install two of these in SLI... That would be awesome.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
I ordered on 16 August 2016 and got the card with launch BIOS. For this BIOS, the fan runs at 48% when idle.

There is a new BIOS available which enables 0 dB at idle and the fan ramps up quite a bit on load. On load, it can be noisy as the fan runs at a higher speed than under the launch BIOS. Do note this when deciding whether to update the BIOS.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
I went from playing Player Unknown Battlegrounds from 720p on Low on a 750ti 2GB.
Now I play the game at 1080p on high/ultra settings. I love this card.

Specs:
8320e eight-core CPU 3.2ghz/4.0ghz turbo
16GB Ram
GTX 1060 6GB Single Fan SC
1TB HD

I have yet to test on other games thoroughly but I can already see a HUGE difference with PUBG.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: I went from a a Geforce 730 to this 1060 and am blown away! My games now run on max settings and I have no problems out of anything. My only drawback, however small it is, was that the cable included with said product did not integrate with my pc in any way. I had to order 6 new cables (since amazon doesn't allow the purchase of 1 of each) to get it connected to my MOBO power. I needed a new sata cable (I purchased a 3 pack, wasteful) and a sata to 6-pin connector (again, a 3 pack, and again, a waste of my money) but in the end it was well worth it with the performance I've received

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: There are plenty of reviews that cover performance of the GTX 1060, the only thing I'd like to caution prospective buyers about is that the single fan can struggle under high loads depending on the airflow of your case. I originally had the card in a Frankenstein dell case from like 2006 (I built the computer in college and saved money where I could). The only upside to the case was that it had an extraordinary amount of fans (10 fans, 2 x 140mm intake, 2 x 120 mm intake, and 6 x 120 exhaust) so I never noticed temps above 50 C. I have since transplanted the card into the NZXT H510i which has two intake and two exhaust fans and under load the card will get routinely get up to 75 - 80 C even with all fans working at max rpm. Other than that I am quite happy with the performance.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: I have yet to have any sort of any problem playing games on this.
Customer Review: I've played Sea of Thieves on this, Apex, Fortnite, GTA V and a few others on relativity high settings and they all hold a steady 100fps and tweaking settings right I've found they can all hold the steady 144 with only occasionally going to medium high settings. Definitely a good card to start off on even competitively just definitely plan on upgrading in the future unless your perfectly comfortable with your current FPS and all that. I just got this a month ago or so and I'm sure I am comfortable with this for at least the next 6-12 months.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Fast and cheap. Temps never get above 65C-70C. Between this and the 970 from last gen, I feel like I've had perfect price:performance ratios two graphics cards in a row. I'm using this to run a 3440x1440 ultrawide and have no issues. I obviously run less taxing games - either ones several years old or undemanding games like Diablo3. Despite the smaller PCB and single fan, this thing never gets hot or throttles due to temps.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: All you really need for playing today's, and tomorrow's, games
Customer Review:
This card is fantastic. It replaced an R7 260X with 1GB of RAM, and the performance difference is quite noticeable. All 1080p resolutions, 60+ fps, mostly high settings, and buttery smooth response. Honestly, who needs much more than that?

We are living in a golden age, people. I expect to get three to five more years of use out of this little powerhouse. I highly recommend it!

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: I got this because I’m too cheap and I kept reading this can handle most games on “Ultra” graphics settings. So far there’s only been a few that have prevented running at at least 60 FPS. If you too are cheap don’t hesitate to grab up this card.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: I got a new 4k monitor for black friday. Time to get a new card right? The gtx 1060 pushes Laura Croft tomb raider game in 4k on high settings @ 60fps. Ultra settings @25 fps. 3840x2160 resolution

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Ignore any other review claiming that the card is noisy. I have set the fan to 80% all the time and it is nearly silent. I upgraded from a 270X, and let me just say that was a noisy card. At 40% fan, you could hear it 30 feet away. In general I am pleased with this card. I got the 3GB version, but really, there just aren't many games that need 6gb or 8gb. I would say that this is the perfect card for 1080P gamers. Even competitively, you really have all the speed that you need. Hopefully it lasts me 2-3 years.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Good but make sure hardware is compatible.
Customer Review:
Graphics card works great for what you need. Make sure the motherboard is compatible with this graphics card before you buy it. I didn’t do too much research and ended up having to get a DVI-Dto HDMI adapter so I could get video output on my screen.

Other than that the box came with everything I need and it was a simple install.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: A great value at $250 in December, not so much at $650 in January.
Customer Review:
Pros: It fits and is super stable in my small case (Alienware X51 R3), and runs all my games in fantastic detail. Most of them at 4K, a few are dialed back for thermal reasons, still much better than "full HD." It was a great value in December at $250.

Cons: It's excessively noisy (70dB, on par with a hair dryer), because it has only one fan and my case is small. If you are buying this card for a small case, you may encounter the same issue. The management software is counterintuitive. This experience is absolutely not worth the current price of $650 (or more) as of 1/22/18.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Only lasted 2 years. Kept up to date on drivers and one day it just went dead. Been less than 1.5 years old and I really didn’t put any major strain or heavy graphic games on it.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: sometimes you need to play with the graphics settings but still able to achieve an excellent gaming experience
Customer Review:
Excellente graphic card. I can play most 2015 - 2016 games on ultra settings 1080P 60FPS without any problems. For 2017 triple games, sometimes you need to play with the graphics settings but still able to achieve an excellent gaming experience.

The GE experience software also make a nice job, optimizing each game automatically to the highest settings according to your PC hardware

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: If you have the money, go ahead and get the 6GB version of this card. Many games need about 4 - 5GB of VRAM (looking at you GTA 5) when set to max settings. Overall this is still a solid card and performs well when paired with a proper intel CPU. I would highly recommend this for any budget build for early 2017.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: This card is made with hynix memory, these are not the Samsung or micron versions. On the surface they seem the same, but in benchmarks they are about 10% poorer in performance. Also, the card I received is very loud. Not sure the issue, the card does room unusually warm under stress. Idle it's about 30c, but anything more gets you to 50c, then consistent load it hits 65c. I may have to request a replacement, as longevity and quality is a concern for me.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Replaced a GTX 970 card that died from moisture exposure in teenage son's PC. Easy to install, drivers went through without a hitch and he was back up and running in no time. There was a noticeable difference in performance as well, much higher fps in games he's been playing for a while, and he fould in the newer titles he could turn up many of the graphical options he'd previous disabled for performance issues, most with out any impact to the higher fps the new card put out. All in all a win, and a lesson learned about water placement and gaming computers in one's room.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Very loud. Would not recommend this card if you plan on playing graphically intensive games like PUBG.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 SC GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC), 06G-P4-6163-KR was the Card i bought. I noticed that several cards are lumped together for a combined review. I was replacing a 660 because a few games were experiencing slow frames. The 660 was a great card. i also have a 1070 in another PC (great card) This card ran So hot it could not even run the Software it Came with. So I uninstalled everything reinstalled it clean. but It would pause when opening folders. Fan was on High Speed.. and Crashed with the provided software for Benchmarks. It is possible I got a bad Card but it just seemed to been cooled terribly. Amazon Was Very Good about letting me return the Card. I regretted buying it 2 hours after installing it. 5 stars for Amazon Support. but in my experance I can not recommend this card in good faith. All reviews I read on and off this site raved about this card. I am not attacking EVGA i've have had many of their cards and worked fantastic. Again I could have just received a bad card, But i was not brave enough to try it again.next time i will Get a card with Pipes, or at least two fans.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR

Customer Review: I bought a few of these, these are the best for the size/price/performance. This card also includes a PCI-E power adapter if you do not have one on your power supply (rare, but a nice touch). Overall great, only gtx1060 I found better is the MSI Twin Frozr Gaming X , but that one is dual fan and HUGE. Performance wise it is about the same but the twin frozr design is really nice for overclocking/aesthetics at night (RGB LED's)

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Buy a version with a 2 fan cooler!
Customer Review: A good quality card that plays through most modern games at High or Ultra settings. However, the single fan version is significantly louder than the dual fan version. Unless you're constrained by a tiny case go for one of the models with a dual fan cooler. And if the price of the 1070 continues to decrease, you're much better off getting that card from both noise and performance perspectives..

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: This is a wonderful graphics card for a starters build Gaming PC. I had no problems installing it or anything. My only complaint is that I didnt have a disc driver at the time I installed it so I had to google and spend an hour or so figuring out how to install the driver for the graphic card. But other than that this is a wonderful buy and I dont regret it at all.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Just updated a Dell XPS 8700 desktop with the EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING ACX 2.0 (Single Fan) 6GB GDDR5 -- and the installation could not have been easier. Old card out...new card in...turn on machine...that easy. After, I did install GeForce Experience to keep GPU drivers up to date.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: A lot of people knock this card for having only 3G of memory. I agree that EVGA should have given it a different number than the full version but for my purposes of a relatively cheap card for my 2nd computer it is doing just fine. Yes, if you are running a game with a huge number of textures you will take a bit of a hit or may need to turn down the video quality but given the out of control prices on GPUs right now, this is doing the job just fine.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: My son needed a faster card for his computer at school (for programming?) So, I got him this. He swears it's not for gaming. Well, he has good grades, so why not? This card dropped in to replace an older Nvidia card and runs just fine. I did have to upgrade his power supply in his Dell tower, but that was expected. Great card at a reasonable price.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Good card for price and profile
Customer Review:
Despite it being a x60 line card it is really good (though it is paired with an old X6 1090T). Stays cool yet provides a good experience. I haven't benchmarked as I only care about being able to play games.

Was having some problems with games but found CPU was the problem (thought it was maybe gpu overheating given its not as large heatsink). Even thought it was the VRMs so heatsinked those as well. Then finally got a non-stock cooler for my CPU and that resolved the issues.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: This bad boy is great for 1080p gaming. If you plan on sticking with 1080p for a while you'd do yourself a favor to pick this up. If you want to do modern or other graphically intensive titles/projects @ 1440p go ahead and get the 1070 if you can spare the extra cash. You'll get a better experience and it'll be a bit more future proof. But as far as a mid-range card is concerned, this one is awesome, plus, in my opinion, I love the smaller size on it. It's a cute little card. :)

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Runs a little hot, use EVGA Precision OC to remedy the heat, all and all, a good card.
Customer Review: an excellent upgrade from a last gen card, just be careful when it comes to airflow, the ACX 2.0 single fans are way smaller than you'd expect, It'll happily sit at 55-60c running Skyrim maxed all day, but you really should run EVGA Precision X to manually remap the fans, otherwise the fans won't even turn on until it hits 60c. With fans set to "aggressive" preset, it will idle happily at 38-40c. All and all, a good card for the money, assuming Miners havent bought them all. Only real problem is trying to fit an aftermarket cooler

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Great colors for Photoshop CC and Video production
Customer Review: I'm no gamer, only got this for multi-monitor 4k support. Worked great on my Dell XPS 8900 without having to upgrade the power supply. As an added benefit, the color on this EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 looks way better than the older GeForce GTX 745 that it replaced. Text is sharp and colors are beautiful. Those that edit in Photoshop & need charts for daytrading will love it.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: The problem with this product, which is well documented ...
Customer Review: The problem with this product, which is well documented ( I found this out after the purchase), is that there are multiple manufacturers of the memory. Two of the three memory vendors run slower than one. There is no way to know what you have until you plug it in your system. Otherwise, it works as advertised. I have seven of these cards. 4 of the 7 run slower than 3 (Mining ETH... fast cards run at 23 Mh/s, slow cards can not get beyond 19 Mh/s)

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Upgraded my PC with this card to run Oculus VR and flight simulation. Works great. Runs every application at high frame rates even when most all graphics features are set to max. Quite, but does get a little warm which was expected. Fit perfectly in my ASUS ROG G20aj. Running a 3 monitor set up.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: I bought this for my son to play Overwatch. Works pretty well except that his PC doesn't have sufficient cooling so every now and then the PC would freeze up. I have him open the case and problem goes away. Not the graphic card's fault though. I would say it's a given that you need a good, quality fan (or other means) to cool the graphics card for these high performance cards.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Bought this for my Micro ITX build and paired it with a Asrock AB350 Gaming Motherboard and a Rysen 5 2600 and it just does not quit. Plays anything I throw at it and was a huge upgrade from what I had before. Been using it for over 8 months now I think and just runs flawless. Highly recommend on a budget although the new stuff is on the market now. Almost time to build a new one...lol

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Excellent Mid to Upper Level Video Card
Customer Review: Not the fastest on the market but I game on a single 1920 x 1080 monitor. Have run Counter Strike, CS GO, Metro 2033 Redux, Metro Last Light Redux, Fallout 4, Skyrim, Deus Ex, and several more FPS's Never an issue at High or Ultra High. Frame rates always over 60 so smooth action.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: I can't believe I was able to get this 6 ...
Customer Review: I can't believe I was able to get this 6 GB 1060 for only $209 right before the miners came crashing in. For that price, I would give this more stars if I could, but unfortunately I can only give it 5. It's worth every penny and much, much more.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Single Fan can fit in a small tower.
Customer Review: I needed something to upgrade my stock's graphic's card due to the game I'm playing and I was looking pretty hard for graphics card that may fit my tower. Then I bumped into this and bought it in hopes it can fit a small tower. Which it can! Graphics is very nice and I love how you can adjust with its settings. I'm not the type of person to go out of my way to build my own PC just for one game. Everything in this tower is stock except for power supply and graphics card.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: It was a great card. Looked nice. Couldn't play on it thanks to EVGA's poor quality, brand new 80+ Gold rated power supply.
Customer Review: It was a great card. Looked nice. Couldn't play on it because my brand new EVGA 80+ Gold rated power supply burned out after only six hours of being on. So I sold the card locally for what I paid for it, disassembled my rig, sold other parts from it, pocketed the $540 I made from it all and never looked back. Cheers!

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review Title: Good performance, not a fan of the fan
Customer Review:
Works well, performance is good. After 2300RPM the fan sounds more like a jet than a fan, don’t let the card get there. I prefer throttling to be honest. The vast majority of the air is exhausted into the PC, from the front of the back (I consider the back to be where the ports are).

I bought this one due to length restrictions. I was hoping it exhausted more air to the outside of the case.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review:
It does the job as well as any other 1060 GPU. But it does spin up pretty high and makes slight buzzing sound especially when switching scenes in a game ie. you die and it has to render a totally new location immediately.
I am a fan of EVGA video cards but in this case I would recommend going with a dual fan GPU or a 1070 instead of this model.

GPU Name: EVGA GeForce GTX 1060 GAMING, ACX 2.0 (Single Fan), 6GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 06G-P4-6161-KR
Customer Review: Purchased this in 2018 and has held up into 2019 with no issues, still playing modern games at excellent fps and resolutions.
